verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:1
verses.text: Life of Antony.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:2
verses.text: The life and conversation of our holy Father, Antony: written and sent to the monks in foreign parts by our Father among the Saints, Athanasius, Bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:3
verses.text: Athanasius the bishop to the brethren in foreign parts.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:4
verses.text: You have entered upon a noble rivalry with the monks of Egypt by your determination either to equal or surpass them in your training in the way of virtue.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:5
verses.text: For by this time there are monasteries among you, and the name of monk receives public recognition.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:6
verses.text: With reason, therefore, all men will approve this determination, and in answer to your prayers God will give its fulfilment.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:7
verses.text: Now since you asked me to give you an account of the blessed Antony's way of life, and are wishful to learn how he began the discipline, who and what manner of man he was previous to this, how he closed his life, and whether the things told of him are true, that you also may bring yourselves to imitate him, I very readily accepted your behest, for to me also the bare recollection of Antony is a great accession of help.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:8
verses.text: And I know that you, when you have heard, apart from your admiration of the man, will be wishful to emulate his determination; seeing that for monks the life of Antony is a sufficient pattern of discipline.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:9
verses.text: Wherefore do not refuse credence to what you have heard from those who brought tidings of him; but think rather that they have told you only a few things, for at all events they scarcely can have given circumstances of so great import in any detail.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:10
verses.text: And because I at your request have called to mind a few circumstances about him, and shall send as much as I can tell in a letter, do not neglect to question those who sail from here: for possibly when all have told their tale, the account will hardly be in proportion to his merits.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:11
verses.text: On account of this I was desirous, when I received your letter, to send for certain of the monks, those especially who were wont to be more frequently with him, that if I could learn any fresh details I might send them to you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:12
verses.text: But since the season for sailing was coming to an end and the letter-carrier urgent, I hastened to write to your piety what I myself know, having seen him many times, and what I was able to learn from him, for I was his attendant for a long time, and poured water on his hands; in all points being mindful of the truth, that no one should disbelieve through hearing too much, nor on the other hand by hearing too little should despise the man.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:14
verses.text: Antony you must know was by descent an Egyptian: his parents were of good family and possessed considerable wealth, and as they were Christians he also was reared in the same Faith.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:15
verses.text: In infancy he was brought up with his parents, knowing nought else but them and his home.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:16
verses.text: But when he was grown and arrived at boyhood, and was advancing in years, he could not endure to learn letters, not caring to associate with other boys; but all his desire was, as it is written of Jacob, to live a plain man at home.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:17
verses.text: With his parents he used to attend the Lord's House, and neither as a child was he idle nor when older did he despise them; but was both obedient to his father and mother and attentive to what was read, keeping in his heart what was profitable in what he heard.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 1:18
verses.text: And though as a child brought up in moderate affluence, he did not trouble his parents for varied or luxurious fare, nor was this a source of pleasure to him; but was content simply with what he found nor sought anything further.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 2:2
verses.text: After the death of his father and mother he was left alone with one little sister: his age was about eighteen or twenty, and on him the care both of home and sister rested.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 2:3
verses.text: Now it was not six months after the death of his parents, and going according to custom into the Lord's House, he communed with himself and reflected as he walked how the Apostles left all and followed the Saviour; and how they in the Acts sold their possessions and brought and laid them at the Apostles' feet for distribution to the needy, and what and how great a hope was laid up for them in heaven.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 2:4
verses.text: Pondering over these things he entered the church, and it happened the Gospel was being read, and he heard the Lord saying to the rich man, 'If thou wouldest be perfect, go and sell that thou hast and give to the poor; and come follow Me and thou shalt have treasure in heaven.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 2:5
verses.text: ' Antony, as though God had put him in mind of the Saints, and the passage had been read on his account, went out immediately from the church, and gave the possessions of his forefathers to the villagers—they were three hundred acres, productive and very fair—that they should be no more a clog upon himself and his sister.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 2:6
verses.text: And all the rest that was movable he sold, and having got together much money he gave it to the poor, reserving a little however for his sister's sake.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 3:2
verses.text: And again as he went into the church, hearing the Lord say in the Gospel, 'be not anxious for the morrow,' he could stay no longer, but went out and gave those things also to the poor.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 3:3
verses.text: Having committed his sister to known and faithful virgins, and put her into a convent to be brought up, he henceforth devoted himself outside his house to discipline, taking heed to himself and training himself with patience.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 3:4
verses.text: For there were not yet so many monasteries in Egypt, and no monk at all knew of the distant desert; but all who wished to give heed to themselves practised the discipline in solitude near their own village.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 3:5
verses.text: Now there was then in the next village an old man who had lived the life of a hermit from his youth up.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 3:6
verses.text: Antony, after he had seen this man, imitated him in piety.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 3:7
verses.text: And at first he began to abide in places outside the village: then if he heard of a good man anywhere, like the prudent bee, he went forth and sought him, nor turned back to his own palace until he had seen him; and he returned, having got from the good man as it were supplies for his journey in the way of virtue.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 3:8
verses.text: So dwelling there at first, he confirmed his purpose not to return to the abode of his fathers nor to the remembrance of his kinsfolk; but to keep all his desire and energy for perfecting his discipline.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 3:9
verses.text: He worked, however, with his hands, having heard, 'he who is idle let him not eat,' and part he spent on bread and part he gave to the needy.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 3:10
verses.text: And he was constant in prayer, knowing that a man ought to pray in secret unceasingly.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 3:11
verses.text: For he had given such heed to what was read that none of the things that were written fell from him to the ground, but he remembered all, and afterwards his memory served him for books.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 4:2
verses.text: Thus conducting himself, Antony was beloved by all.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 4:3
verses.text: He subjected himself in sincerity to the good men whom he visited, and learned thoroughly where each surpassed him in zeal and discipline.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 4:4
verses.text: He observed the graciousness of one; the unceasing prayer of another; he took knowledge of another's freedom from anger and another's loving-kindness; he gave heed to one as he watched, to another as he studied; one he admired for his endurance, another for his fasting and sleeping on the ground; the meekness of one and the long-suffering of another he watched with care, while he took note of the piety towards Christ and the mutual love which animated all.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 4:5
verses.text: Thus filled, he returned to his own place of discipline, and henceforth would strive to unite the qualities of each, and was eager to show in himself the virtues of all.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 4:6
verses.text: With others of the same age he had no rivalry; save this only, that he should not be second to them in higher things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 4:7
verses.text: And this he did so as to hurt the feelings of nobody, but made them rejoice over him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 4:8
verses.text: So all they of that village and the good men in whose intimacy he was, when they saw that he was a man of this sort, used to call him God-beloved.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 4:9
verses.text: And some welcomed him as a son, others as a brother.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:2
verses.text: But the devil, who hates and envies what is good, could not endure to see such a resolution in a youth, but endeavoured to carry out against him what he had been wont to effect against others.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:3
verses.text: First of all he tried to lead him away from the discipline, whispering to him the remembrance of his wealth, care for his sister, claims of kindred, love of money, love of glory, the various pleasures of the table and the other relaxations of life, and at last the difficulty of virtue and the labour of it; he suggested also the infirmity of the body and the length of the time.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:4
verses.text: In a word he raised in his mind a great dust of debate, wishing to debar him from his settled purpose.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:5
verses.text: But when the enemy saw himself to be too weak for Antony's determination, and that he rather was conquered by the other's firmness, overthrown by his great faith and falling through his constant prayers, then at length putting his trust in the weapons which are 'in the navel of his belly' and boasting in them—for they are his first snare for the young—he attacked the young man, disturbing him by night and harassing him by day, so that even the onlookers saw the struggle which was going on between them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:6
verses.text: The one would suggest foul thoughts and the other counter them with prayers: the one fire him with lust, the other, as one who seemed to blush, fortify his body with faith, prayers, and fasting.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:7
verses.text: And the devil, unhappy wight, one night even took upon him the shape of a woman and imitated all her acts simply to beguile Antony.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:8
verses.text: But he, his mind filled with Christ and the nobility inspired by Him, and considering the spirituality of the soul, quenched the coal of the other's deceit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:9
verses.text: Again the enemy suggested the ease of pleasure.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:10
verses.text: But he like a man filled with rage and grief turned his thoughts to the threatened fire and the gnawing worm, and setting these in array against his adversary, passed through the temptation unscathed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:11
verses.text: All this was a source of shame to his foe.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:12
verses.text: For he, deeming himself like God, was now mocked by a young man; and he who boasted himself against flesh and blood was being put to flight by a man in the flesh.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 5:13
verses.text: For the Lord was working with Antony—the Lord who for our sake took flesh and gave the body victory over the devil, so that all who truly fight can say, 'not I but the grace of God which was with me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 6:2
verses.text: At last when the dragon could not even thus overthrow Antony, but saw himself thrust out of his heart, gnashing his teeth as it is written, and as it were beside himself, he appeared to Antony like a black boy, taking a visible shape in accordance with the colour of his mind.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 6:3
verses.text: And cringing to him, as it were, he plied him with thoughts no longer, for guileful as he was, he had been worsted, but at last spoke in human voice and said, 'Many I deceived, many I cast down; but now attacking thee and thy labours as I had many others, I proved weak.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 6:4
verses.text: ' When Antony asked, Who art thou who speakest thus with me? he answered with a lamentable voice, 'I am the friend of whoredom, and have taken upon me incitements which lead to it against the young.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 6:5
verses.text: I am called the spirit of lust.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 6:6
verses.text: How many have I deceived who wished to live soberly, how many are the chaste whom by my incitements I have over-persuaded! I am he on account of whom also the prophet reproves those who have fallen, saying, "Ye have been caused to err by the spirit of whoredom".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 6:7
verses.text: For by me they have been tripped up.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 6:8
verses.text: I am he who have so often troubled thee and have so often been overthrown by thee.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 6:9
verses.text: ' But Antony having given thanks to the Lord, with good courage said to him, 'Thou art very despicable then, for thou art black-hearted and weak as a child.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 6:10
verses.text: Henceforth I shall have no trouble from thee, "for the Lord is my helper, and I shall look down on mine enemies".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 6:11
verses.text: ' Having heard this, the black one straightway fled, shuddering at the words and dreading any longer even to come near the man.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:2
verses.text: This was Antony's first struggle against the devil, or rather this victory was the Saviour's work in Antony, 'Who condemned sin in the flesh that the ordinance of the law might be fulfilled in us who walk not after the flesh but after the spirit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:3
verses.text: ' But neither did Antony, although the evil one had fallen, henceforth relax his care and despise him; nor did the enemy as though conquered cease to lay snares for him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:4
verses.text: For again he went round as a lion seeking some occasion against him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:5
verses.text: But Antony having learned from the Scriptures that the devices of the devil are many, zealously continued the discipline, reckoning that though the devil had not been able to deceive his heart by bodily pleasure, he would endeavour to ensnare him by other means.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:6
verses.text: For the demon loves sin.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:7
verses.text: Wherefore more and more he repressed the body and kept it in subjection, lest haply having conquered on one side, he should be dragged down on the other.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:8
verses.text: He therefore planned to accustom himself to a severer mode of life.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:9
verses.text: And many marvelled, but he himself used to bear the labour easily; for the eagerness of soul, through the length of time it had abode in him, had wrought a good habit in him, so that taking but little initiation from others he shewed great zeal in this matter.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:10
verses.text: He kept vigil to such an extent that he often continued the whole night without sleep; and this not once but often, to the marvel of others.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:11
verses.text: He ate once a day, after sunset, sometimes once in two days, and often even in four.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:12
verses.text: His food was bread and salt, his drink, water only.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:13
verses.text: Of flesh and wine it is superfluous even to speak, since no such thing was found with the other earnest men.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:14
verses.text: A rush mat served him to sleep upon, but for the most part he lay upon the bare ground.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:15
verses.text: He would not anoint himself with oil, saying it behoved young men to be earnest in training and not to seek what would enervate the body; but they must accustom it to labour, mindful of the Apostle's words, 'when I am weak, then am I strong.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:16
verses.text: ' 'For,' said he, 'the fibre of the soul is then sound when the pleasures of the body are diminished.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:17
verses.text: ' And he had come to this truly wonderful conclusion, 'that progress in virtue, and retirement from the world for the sake of it, ought not to be measured by time, but by desire and fixity of purpose.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:18
verses.text: ' He at least gave no thought to the past, but day by day, as if he were at the beginning of his discipline, applied greater pains for advancement, often repeating to himself the saying of Paul: 'Forgetting the things which are behind and stretching forward to the things which are before.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:19
verses.text: ' He was also mindful of the words spoken by the prophet Elias, 'the Lord liveth before whose presence I stand to-day.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:20
verses.text: ' For he observed that in saying 'to-day' the prophet did not compute the time that had gone by: but daily as though ever commencing he eagerly endeavoured to make himself fit to appear before God, being pure in heart and ever ready to submit to His counsel, and to Him alone.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 7:21
verses.text: And he used to say to himself that from the life of the great Elias the hermit ought to see his own as in a mirror.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 8:2
verses.text: Thus tightening his hold upon himself, Antony departed to the tombs, which happened to be at a distance from the village; and having bid one of his acquaintances to bring him bread at intervals of many days, he entered one of the tombs, and the other having shut the door on him, he remained within alone.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 8:3
verses.text: And when the enemy could not endure it, but was even fearful that in a short time Antony would fill the desert with the discipline, coming one night with a multitude of demons, he so cut him with stripes that he lay on the ground speechless from the excessive pain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 8:4
verses.text: For he affirmed that the torture had been so excessive that no blows inflicted by man could ever have caused him such torment.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 8:5
verses.text: But by the Providence of God—for the Lord never overlooks them that hope in Him—the next day his acquaintance came bringing him the loaves.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 8:6
verses.text: And having opened the door and seeing him lying on the ground as though dead, he lifted him up and carried him to the church in the village, and laid him upon the ground.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 8:7
verses.text: And many of his kinsfolk and the villagers sat around Antony as round a corpse.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 8:8
verses.text: But about midnight he came to himself and arose, and when he saw them all asleep and his comrade alone watching, he motioned with his head for him to approach, and asked him to carry him again to the tombs without waking anybody.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:2
verses.text: He was carried therefore by the man, and as he was wont, when the door was shut he was within alone.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:3
verses.text: And he could not stand up on account of the blows, but he prayed as he lay.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:4
verses.text: And after he had prayed, he said with a shout, Here am I, Antony; I flee not from your stripes, for even if you inflict more nothing shall separate me from the love of Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:5
verses.text: And then he sang, 'though a camp be set against me, my heart shall not be afraid.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:6
verses.text: ' These were the thoughts and words of this ascetic.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:7
verses.text: But the enemy, who hates good, marvelling that after the blows he dared to return, called together his hounds and burst forth, 'Ye see,' said he, 'that neither by the spirit of lust nor by blows did we stay the man, but that he braves us, let us attack him in another fashion.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:8
verses.text: ' But changes of form for evil are easy for the devil, so in the night they made such a din that the whole of that place seemed to be shaken by an earthquake, and the demons as if breaking the four walls of the dwelling seemed to enter through them, coming in the likeness of beasts and creeping things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:9
verses.text: And the place was on a sudden filled with the forms of lions, bears, leopards, bulls, serpents, asps, scorpions, and wolves, and each of them was moving according to his nature.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:10
verses.text: The lion was roaring, wishing to attack, the bull seeming to toss with its horns, the serpent writhing but unable to approach, and the wolf as it rushed on was restrained; altogether the noises of the apparitions, with their angry ragings, were dreadful.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:11
verses.text: But Antony, stricken and goaded by them, felt bodily pains severer still.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:12
verses.text: He lay watching, however, with unshaken soul, groaning from bodily anguish; but his mind was clear, and as in mockery he said, 'If there had been any power in you, it would have sufficed had one of you come, but since the Lord hath made you weak, you attempt to terrify me by numbers: and a proof of your weakness is that you take the shapes of brute beasts.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:13
verses.text: ' And again with boldness he said, 'If you are able, and have received power against me, delay not to attack; but if you are unable, why trouble me in vain? For faith in our Lord is a seal and a wall of safety to us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 9:14
verses.text: ' So after many attempts they gnashed their teeth upon him, because they were mocking themselves rather than him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 10:2
verses.text: Nor was the Lord then forgetful of Antony's wrestling, but was at hand to help him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 10:3
verses.text: So looking up he saw the roof as it were opened, and a ray of light descending to him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 10:4
verses.text: The demons suddenly vanished, the pain of his body straightway ceased, and the building was again whole.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 10:5
verses.text: But Antony feeling the help, and getting his breath again, and being freed from pain, besought the vision which had appeared to him, saying, 'Where wert thou? Why didst thou not appear at the beginning to make my pains to cease?' And a voice came to him, 'Antony, I was here, but I waited to see thy fight; wherefore since thou hast endured, and hast not been worsted, I will ever be a succour to thee, and will make thy name known everywhere.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 10:6
verses.text: ' Having heard this, Antony arose and prayed, and received such strength that he perceived that he had more power in his body than formerly.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 10:7
verses.text: And he was then about thirty-five years old.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 11:2
verses.text: And on the day following he went forth still more eagerly bent on the service of God and having fallen in with the old man he had met previously, he asked him to dwell with him in the desert.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 11:3
verses.text: But when the other declined on account of his great age, and because as yet there was no such custom, Antony himself set off forthwith to the mountain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 11:4
verses.text: And yet again the enemy seeing his zeal and wishing to hinder it, cast in his way what seemed to be a great silver dish.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 11:5
verses.text: But Antony, seeing the guile of the Evil One, stood, and having looked on the dish, he put the devil in it to shame, saying, 'Whence comes a dish in the desert? This road is not well-worn, nor is there here a trace of any wayfarer; it could not have fallen without being missed on account of its size; and he who had lost it having turned back, to seek it, would have found it, for it is a desert place.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 11:6
verses.text: This is some wile of the devil.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 11:7
verses.text: O thou Evil One, not with this shalt thou hinder my purpose; let it go with thee to destruction.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 11:8
verses.text: ' And when Antony had said this it vanished like smoke from the face of fire.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 12:2
verses.text: Then again as he went on he saw what was this time not visionary, but real gold scattered in the way.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 12:3
verses.text: But whether the devil showed it, or some better power to try the athlete and show the Evil One that Antony truly cared nought for money, neither he told nor do we know.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 12:4
verses.text: But it is certain that that which appeared was gold.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 12:5
verses.text: And Antony marvelled at the quantity, but passed it by as though he were going over fire; so he did not even turn, but hurried on at a run to lose sight of the place.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 12:6
verses.text: More and more confirmed in his purpose, he hurried to the mountain, and having found a fort, so long deserted that it was full of creeping things, on the other side of the river; he crossed over to it and dwelt there.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 12:7
verses.text: The reptiles, as though some one were chasing them, immediately left the place.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 12:8
verses.text: But he built up the entrance completely, having stored up loaves for six months—this is a custom of the Thebans, and the loaves often remain fresh a whole year—and as he found water within, he descended as into a shrine, and abode within by himself, never going forth nor looking at any one who came.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 12:9
verses.text: Thus he employed a long time training himself, and received loaves, let down from above, twice in the year.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 13:2
verses.text: But those of his acquaintances who came, since he did not permit them to enter, often used to spend days and nights outside, and heard as it were crowds within clamouring, dinning, sending forth piteous voices and crying, 'Go from what is ours.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 13:3
verses.text: What dost thou even in the desert? Thou canst not abide our attack.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 13:4
verses.text: ' So at first those outside thought there were some men fighting with him, and that they had entered by ladders; but when stooping down they saw through a hole there was nobody, they were afraid, accounting them to be demons, and they called on Antony.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 13:5
verses.text: Them he quickly heard, though he had not given a thought to the demons, and coming to the door he besought them to depart and not to be afraid, 'for thus,' said he, 'the demons make their seeming onslaughts against those who are cowardly.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 13:6
verses.text: Sign yourselves therefore with the cross, and depart boldly, and let these make sport for themselves.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 13:7
verses.text: ' So they departed fortified with the sign of the Cross.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 13:8
verses.text: But he remained in no wise harmed by the evil spirits, nor was he wearied with the contest, for there came to his aid visions from above, and the weakness of the foe relieved him of much trouble and armed him with greater zeal.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 13:9
verses.text: For his acquaintances used often to come expecting to find him dead, and would hear him singing, 'Let God arise and let His enemies be scattered, let them also that hate Him flee before His face.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 13:10
verses.text: As smoke vanisheth, let them vanish; as wax melteth before the face of fire, so let the sinners perish from the face of God;' and again, 'All nations compassed me about, and in the name of the Lord I requited them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 14:2
verses.text: And so for nearly twenty years he continued training himself in solitude, never going forth, and but seldom seen by any.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 14:3
verses.text: After this, when many were eager and wishful to imitate his discipline, and his acquaintances came and began to cast down and wrench off the door by force, Antony, as from a shrine, came forth initiated in the mysteries and filled with the Spirit of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 14:4
verses.text: Then for the first time he was seen outside the fort by those who came to see him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 14:5
verses.text: And they, when they saw him, wondered at the sight, for he had the same habit of body as before, and was neither fat, like a man without exercise, nor lean from fasting and striving with the demons, but he was just the same as they had known him before his retirement.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 14:6
verses.text: And again his soul was free from blemish, for it was neither contracted as if by grief, nor relaxed by pleasure, nor possessed by laughter or dejection, for he was not troubled when he beheld the crowd, nor overjoyed at being saluted by so many.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 14:7
verses.text: But he was altogether even as being guided by reason, and abiding in a natural state.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 14:8
verses.text: Through him the Lord healed the bodily ailments of many present, and cleansed others from evil spirits.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 14:9
verses.text: And He gave grace to Antony in speaking, so that he consoled many that were sorrowful, and set those at variance at one, exhorting all to prefer the love of Christ before all that is in the world.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 14:10
verses.text: And while he exhorted and advised them to remember the good things to come, and the loving-kindness of God towards us, 'Who spared not His own Son, but delivered Him up for us all,' he persuaded many to embrace the solitary life.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 14:11
verses.text: And thus it happened in the end that cells arose even in the mountains, and the desert was colonised by monks, who came forth from their own people, and enrolled themselves for the citizenship in the heavens.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 15:2
verses.text: But when he was obliged to cross the Arsenoitic Canal—and the occasion of it was the visitation of the brethren—the canal was full of crocodiles.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 15:3
verses.text: And by simply praying, he entered it, and all they with him, and passed over in safety.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 15:4
verses.text: And having returned to his cell, he applied himself to the same noble and valiant exercises; and by frequent conversation he increased the eagerness of those already monks, stirred up in most of the rest the love of the discipline, and speedily by the attraction of his words cells multiplied, and he directed them all as a father.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 16:2
verses.text: One day when he had gone forth because all the monks had assembled to him and asked to hear words from him, he spoke to them in the Egyptian tongue as follows: 'The Scriptures are enough for instruction, but it is a good thing to encourage one another in the faith, and to stir up with words.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 16:3
verses.text: Wherefore you, as children, carry that which you know to your father; and I as the elder share my knowledge and what experience has taught me with you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 16:4
verses.text: Let this especially be the common aim of all, neither to give way having once begun, nor to faint in trouble, nor to say: We have lived in the discipline a long time: but rather as though making a beginning daily let us increase our earnestness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 16:5
verses.text: For the whole life of man is very short, measured by the ages to come, wherefore all our time is nothing compared with eternal life.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 16:6
verses.text: And in the world everything is sold at its price, and a man exchanges one equivalent for another; but the promise of eternal life is bought for a trifle.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 16:7
verses.text: For it is written, "The days of our life in them are threescore years and ten, but if they are in strength, fourscore years, and what is more than these is labour and sorrow".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 16:8
verses.text: Whenever, therefore, we live full fourscore years, or even a hundred in the discipline, not for a hundred years only shall we reign, but instead of a hundred we shall reign for ever and ever.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 16:9
verses.text: And though we fought on earth, we shall not receive our inheritance on earth, but we have the promises in heaven; and having put off the body which is corrupt, we shall receive it incorrupt.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 17:2
verses.text: 'Wherefore, children, let us not faint nor deem that the time is long, or that we are doing something great, "for the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed to us-ward".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 17:3
verses.text: Nor let us think, as we look at the world, that we have renounced anything of much consequence, for the whole earth is very small compared with all the heaven.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 17:4
verses.text: Wherefore if it even chanced that we were lords of all the earth and gave it all up, it would be nought worthy of comparison with the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 17:5
verses.text: For as if a man should despise a copper drachma to gain a hundred drachmas of gold; so if a man were lord of all the earth and were to renounce it, that which he gives up is little, and he receives a hundredfold.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 17:6
verses.text: But if not even the whole earth is equal in value to the heavens, then he who has given up a few acres leaves as it were nothing; and even if he have given up a house or much gold he ought not to boast nor be low-spirited.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 17:7
verses.text: Further, we should consider that even if we do not relinquish them for virtue's sake, still afterwards when we die we shall leave them behind—very often, as the Preacher saith, to those to whom we do not wish.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 17:8
verses.text: Why then should we not give them up for virtue's sake, that we may inherit even a kingdom? Therefore let the desire of possession take hold of no one, for what gain is it to acquire these things which we cannot take with us? Why not rather get those things which we can take away with us—to wit, prudence, justice, temperance, courage, understanding, love, kindness to the poor, faith in Christ, freedom from wrath, hospitality? If we possess these, we shall find them of themselves preparing for us a welcome there in the land of the meek-hearted.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 18:2
verses.text: 'And so from such things let a man persuade himself not to make light of it, especially if he considers that he himself is the servant of the Lord, and ought to serve his Master.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 18:3
verses.text: Wherefore as a servant would not dare to say, because I worked yesterday, I will not work today; and considering the past will do no work in the future; but, as it is written in the Gospel, daily shows the same readiness to please his master, and to avoid risk: so let us daily abide firm in our discipline, knowing that if we are careless for a single day the Lord will not pardon us, for the sake of the past, but will be wrath against us for our neglect.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 18:4
verses.text: As also we have heard in Ezekiel; and as Judas because of one night destroyed his previous labour.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 19:2
verses.text: 'Wherefore, children, let us hold fast our discipline, and let us not be careless.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 19:3
verses.text: For in it the Lord is our fellow-worker, as it is written, "to all that choose the good, God worketh with them for good".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 19:4
verses.text: But to avoid being heedless, it is good to consider the word of the Apostle, "I die daily".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 19:5
verses.text: For if we too live as though dying daily, we shall not sin.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 19:6
verses.text: And the meaning of that saying is, that as we rise day by day we should think that we shall not abide till evening; and again, when about to lie down to sleep, we should think that we shall not rise up.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 19:7
verses.text: For our life is naturally uncertain, and Providence allots it to us daily.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 19:8
verses.text: But thus ordering our daily life, we shall neither fall into sin, nor have a lust for anything, nor cherish wrath against any, nor shall we heap up treasure upon earth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 19:9
verses.text: But, as though under the daily expectation of death, we shall be without wealth, and shall forgive all things to all men, nor shall we retain at all the desire of women or of any other foul pleasure.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 19:10
verses.text: But we shall turn from it as past and gone, ever striving and looking forward to the day of Judgment.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 19:11
verses.text: For the greater dread and danger of torment ever destroys the ease of pleasure, and sets up the soul if it is like to fall.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:2
verses.text: 'Wherefore having already begun and set out in the way of virtue, let us strive the more that we may attain those things that are before.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:3
verses.text: And let no one turn to the things behind, like Lot's wife, all the more so that the Lord hath said, "No man, having put his hand to the plough, and turning back, is fit for the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:4
verses.text: And this turning back is nought else but to feel regret, and to be once more worldly-minded.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:5
verses.text: But fear not to hear of virtue, nor be astonished at the name.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:6
verses.text: For it is not far from us, nor is it without ourselves, but it is within us, and is easy if only we are willing.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:7
verses.text: That they may get knowledge, the Greeks live abroad and cross the sea, but we have no need to depart from home for the sake of the kingdom of heaven, nor to cross the sea for the sake of virtue.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:8
verses.text: For the Lord aforetime hath said, "The kingdom of heaven is within you ".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:9
verses.text: Wherefore virtue hath need at our hands of willingness alone, since it is in us and is formed from us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:10
verses.text: For when the soul hath its spiritual faculty in a natural state virtue is formed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:11
verses.text: And it is in a natural state when it remains as it came into existence.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:12
verses.text: And when it came into existence it was fair and exceeding honest.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:13
verses.text: For this cause Joshua, the son of Nun, in his exhortation said to the people, "Make straight your heart unto the Lord God of Israel," and John, "Make your paths straight".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:14
verses.text: For rectitude of soul consists in its having its spiritual part in its natural state as created.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:15
verses.text: But on the other hand, when it swerves and turns away from its natural state, that is called vice of the soul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:16
verses.text: Thus the matter is not difficult.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:17
verses.text: If we abide as we have been made, we are in a state of virtue, but if we think of ignoble things we shall be accounted evil.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:18
verses.text: If, therefore, this thing had to be acquired from without, it would be difficult in reality; but if it is in us, let us keep ourselves from foul thoughts.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 20:19
verses.text: And as we have received the soul as a deposit, let us preserve it for the Lord, that He may recognise His work as being the same as He made it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 21:2
verses.text: 'And let us strive that wrath rule us not nor lust overcome us, for it is written, "The wrath of man worketh not the righteousness of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 21:3
verses.text: And lust, when it hath conceived, beareth sin, and the sin when it is full grown bringeth forth death".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 21:4
verses.text: Thus living, let us keep guard carefully, and as it is written, "keep our hearts with all watchfulness".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 21:5
verses.text: For we have terrible and crafty foes—the evil spirits—and against them we wrestle, as the Apostle said, "Not against flesh and blood, but against the principalities and against the powers, against the world-rulers of this darkness, against the spiritual hosts of wickedness in the heavenly places".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 21:6
verses.text: Great is their number in the air around us, and they are not far from us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 21:7
verses.text: Now there are great distinctions among them; and concerning their nature and distinctions much could be said, but such a description is for others of greater powers than we possess.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 21:8
verses.text: But at this time it is pressing and necessary for us only to know their wiles against ourselves.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 22:2
verses.text: 'First, therefore, we must know this: that the demons have not been created like what we mean when we call them by that name; for God made nothing evil, but even they have been made good.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 22:3
verses.text: Having fallen, however, from the heavenly wisdom, since then they have been grovelling on earth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 22:4
verses.text: On the one hand they deceived the Greeks with their displays, while out of envy of us Christians they move all things in their desire to hinder us from entry into the heavens; in order that we should not ascend up thither from whence they fell.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 22:5
verses.text: Thus there is need of much prayer and of discipline, that when a man has received through the Spirit the gift of discerning spirits, he may have power to recognise their characteristics: which of them are less and which more evil; of what nature is the special pursuit of each, and how each of them is overthrown and cast out.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 22:6
verses.text: For their villainies and the changes in their plots are many.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 22:7
verses.text: The blessed Apostle and his followers knew such things when they said, "for we are not ignorant of his devices;" and we, from the temptations we have suffered at their hands, ought to correct one another under them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 22:8
verses.text: Wherefore I, having had proof of them, speak as to children.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 23:2
verses.text: 'The demons, therefore, if they see all Christians, and monks especially, labouring cheerfully and advancing, first make an attack by temptation and place hindrances to hamper our way, to wit, evil thoughts.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 23:3
verses.text: But we need not fear their suggestions, for by prayer, fasting, and faith in the Lord their attack immediately fails.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 23:4
verses.text: But even when it does they cease not, but knavishly by subtlety come on again.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 23:5
verses.text: For when they cannot deceive the heart openly with foul pleasures they approach in different guise, and thenceforth shaping displays they attempt to strike fear, changing their shapes, taking the forms of women, wild beasts, creeping things, gigantic bodies, and troops of soldiers.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 23:6
verses.text: But not even then need ye fear their deceitful displays.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 23:7
verses.text: For they are nothing and quickly disappear, especially if a man fortify himself beforehand with faith and the sign of the cross.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 23:8
verses.text: Yet are they bold and very shameless, for if thus they are worsted they make an onslaught in another manner, and pretend to prophesy and foretell the future, and to shew themselves of a height reaching to the roof and of great breadth; that they may stealthily catch by such displays those who could not be deceived by their arguments.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 23:9
verses.text: If here also they find the soul strengthened by faith and a hopeful mind, then they bring their leader to their aid.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:2
verses.text: 'And he said they often appeared as the Lord revealed the devil to Job, saying, "His eyes are as the morning star.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:3
verses.text: From his mouth proceed burning lamps and hearths of fire are cast forth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:4
verses.text: The smoke of a furnace blazing with the fire of coals proceeds from his nostrils.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:5
verses.text: His breath is coals and from his mouth issues flame".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:6
verses.text: When the prince of the demons appears in this wise, the crafty one, as I said before, strikes terror by speaking great things, as again the Lord convicted him saying to Job, for "he counteth iron as straw, and brass as rotten wood, yea he counteth the sea as a pot of ointment, and the depth of the abyss as a captive, and the abyss as a covered walk".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:7
verses.text: And by the prophet, "the enemy said, I will pursue and overtake," and again by another, "I will grasp the whole world in my hand as a nest, and take it up as eggs that have been left".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:8
verses.text: Such, in a word, are their boasts and professions that they may deceive the godly.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:9
verses.text: But not even then ought we, the faithful, to fear his appearance or give heed to his words.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:10
verses.text: For he is a liar and speaketh of truth never a word.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:11
verses.text: And though speaking words so many and so great in his boldness, without doubt, like a dragon he was drawn with a hook by the Saviour, and as a beast of burden he received the halter round his nostrils, and as a runaway his nostrils were bound with a ring, and his lips bored with an armlet.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:12
verses.text: And he was bound by the Lord as a sparrow, that we should mock him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:13
verses.text: And with him are placed the demons his fellows, like serpents and scorpions to be trodden underfoot by us Christians.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:14
verses.text: And the proof of this is that we now live opposed to him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:15
verses.text: For he who threatened to dry the sea and seize upon the world, behold now cannot stay our discipline, nor even me speaking against him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:16
verses.text: Let us then heed not his words, for he is a liar: and let us not fear his visions, seeing that they themselves are deceptive.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:17
verses.text: For that which appears in them is no true light, but they are rather the preludes and likenesses of the fire prepared for the demons who attempt to terrify men with those flames in which they themselves will be burned.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:18
verses.text: Doubtless they appear; but in a moment disappear again, hurting none of the faithful, but bringing with them the likeness of that fire which is about to receive themselves.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 24:19
verses.text: Wherefore it is unfitting that we should fear them on account of these things; for through the grace of Christ all their practices are in vain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 25:2
verses.text: 'Again they are treacherous, and are ready to change themselves into all forms and assume all appearances.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 25:3
verses.text: Very often also without appearing they imitate the music of harp and voice, and recall the words of Scripture.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 25:4
verses.text: Sometimes, too, while we are reading they immediately repeat many times, like an echo, what is read.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 25:5
verses.text: They arouse us from our sleep to prayers; and this constantly, hardly allowing us to sleep at all.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 25:6
verses.text: At another time they assume the appearance of monks and feign the speech of holy men, that by their similarity they may deceive and thus drag their victims where they will.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 25:7
verses.text: But no heed must be paid them even if they arouse to prayer, even if they counsel us not to eat at all, even though they seem to accuse and cast shame upon us for those things which once they allowed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 25:8
verses.text: For they do this not for the sake of piety or truth, but that they may carry off the simple to despair; and that they may say the discipline is useless, and make men loathe the solitary life as a trouble and burden, and hinder those who in spite of them walk in it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 26:2
verses.text: 'Wherefore the prophet sent by the Lord declared them to be wretched, saying: "Wo is he who giveth his neighbours to drink muddy destruction".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 26:3
verses.text: For such practices and devices are subversive of the way which leads to virtue.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 26:4
verses.text: And the Lord Himself, even if the demons spoke the truth,—for they said truly "Thou art the Son of God"—still bridled their mouths and suffered them not to speak; lest haply they should sow their evil along with the truth, and that He might accustom us never to give heed to them even though they appear to speak what is true.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 26:5
verses.text: For it is unseemly that we, having the holy Scriptures and freedom from the Saviour, should be taught by the devil who hath not kept his own order but hath gone from one mind to another.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 26:6
verses.text: Wherefore even when he uses the language of Scripture He forbids him, saying: "But to the sinner said God, Wherefore dost thou declare My ordinances and takest My covenant in thy mouth?" For the demons do all things—they prate, they confuse, they dissemble, they confound—to deceive the simple.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 26:7
verses.text: They din, laugh madly, and whistle; but if no heed is paid to them forthwith they weep and lament as though vanquished.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 27:2
verses.text: 'The Lord therefore, as God, stayed the mouths of the demons: and it is fitting that we, taught by the saints, should do like them and imitate their courage.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 27:3
verses.text: For they when they saw these things used to say: "When the sinner rose against me, I was dumb and humble, and kept silence from good words".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 27:4
verses.text: And again: "But I was as a deaf man and heard not, and as a dumb man who openeth not his mouth, and I became as a man who heareth not".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 27:5
verses.text: So let us neither hear them as being strangers to us, nor give heed to them even though they arouse us to prayer and speak concerning fasting.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 27:6
verses.text: But let us rather apply ourselves to our resolve of discipline, and let us not be deceived by them who do all things in deceit, even though they threaten death.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 27:7
verses.text: For they are weak and can do nought but threaten.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:2
verses.text: 'Already in passing I have spoken on these things, and now I must not shrink from speaking on them at greater length, for to put you in remembrance will be a source of safety.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:3
verses.text: Since the Lord visited earth, the enemy is fallen and his powers weakened.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:4
verses.text: Wherefore although he could do nothing, still like a tyrant, he did not bear his fall quietly, but threatened, though his threats were words only.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:5
verses.text: And let each one of you consider this, and he will be able to despise the demons.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:6
verses.text: Now if they were hampered with such bodies as we are, it would be possible for them to say, "Men when they are hidden we cannot find, but whenever we do find them we do them hurt".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:7
verses.text: And we also by lying in concealment could escape them, shutting the doors against them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:8
verses.text: But if they are not of such a nature as this, but are able to enter in, though the doors be shut, and haunt all the air, both they and their leader the devil, and are wishful for evil and ready to injure; and, as the Saviour said, "From the beginning the devil is a manslayer and a father of vice;" while we, though this is so, are alive, and spend our lives all the more in opposing him; it is plain they are powerless.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:9
verses.text: For place is no hindrance to their plots, nor do they look on us as friends that they should spare us; nor are they lovers of good that they should amend.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:10
verses.text: But on the contrary they are evil, and nothing is so much sought after by them as wounding them that love virtue and fear God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:11
verses.text: But since they have no power to effect anything, they do nought but threaten.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:12
verses.text: But if they could, they would not hesitate, but forthwith work evil (for all their desire is set on this), and especially against us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:13
verses.text: Behold now we are gathered together and speak against them, and they know when we advance they grow weak.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:14
verses.text: If therefore they had power they would permit none of us Christians to live, for godliness is an abomination to a sinner.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:15
verses.text: But since they can do nothing they inflict the greater wounds on themselves; for they can fulfil none of their threats.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:16
verses.text: Next this ought to be considered, that we may be in no fear of them: that if they had the power they would not come in crowds, nor fashion displays, nor with change of form would they frame deceits.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:17
verses.text: But it would suffice that one only should come and accomplish that which he was both able and willing to do: especially as every one who has the power neither slays with display nor strikes fear with tumult, but forthwith makes full use of his authority as he wishes.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:18
verses.text: But the demons as they have no power are like actors on the stage changing their shape and frightening children with tumultuous apparition and various forms: from which they ought rather to be despised as shewing their weakness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:19
verses.text: At least the true angel of the Lord sent against the Assyrian had no need for tumults nor displays from without, nor noises nor rattlings, but in quiet he used his power and forthwith destroyed a hundred and eighty-five thousand.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 28:20
verses.text: But demons like these, who have no power, try to terrify at least by their displays.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 29:2
verses.text: 'But if any one having in mind the history of Job should say, Why then hath the devil gone forth and accomplished all things against him; and stripped him of all his possessions, and slew his children, and smote him with evil ulcers? let such a one, on the other hand, recognise that the devil was not the strong man, but God who delivered Job to him to be tried.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 29:3
verses.text: Certainly he had no power to do anything, but he asked, and having received it, he hath wrought what he did.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 29:4
verses.text: So also from this the enemy is the more to be condemned, for although willing he could not prevail against one just man.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 29:5
verses.text: For if he could have, he would not have asked permission.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 29:6
verses.text: But having asked not once but also a second time, he shows his weakness and want of power.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 29:7
verses.text: And it is no wonder if he could do nothing against Job, when destruction would not have come even on his cattle had not God allowed it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 29:8
verses.text: And he has not the power over swine, for as it is written in the Gospel, they besought the Lord, saying, "Let us enter the swine".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 29:9
verses.text: But if they had power not even against swine, much less have they any over men formed in the image of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 30:2
verses.text: 'So then we ought to fear God only, and despise the demons, and be in no fear of them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 30:3
verses.text: But the more they do these things the more let us intensify our discipline against them, for a good life and faith in God is a great weapon.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 30:4
verses.text: At any rate they fear the fasting, the sleeplessness, the prayers, the meekness, the quietness, the contempt of money and vainglory, the humility, the love of the poor, the alms, the freedom from anger of the ascetics, and, chief of all, their piety towards Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 30:5
verses.text: Wherefore they do all things that they may not have any that trample on them, knowing the grace given to the faithful against them by the Saviour, when He says, "Behold I have given to you power to tread upon serpents and scorpions, and upon all the power of the enemy".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:2
verses.text: 'Wherefore if they pretend to foretell the future, let no one give heed, for often they announce beforehand that the brethren are coming days after.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:3
verses.text: And they do come.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:4
verses.text: The demons, however, do this not from any care for the hearers, but to gain their trust, and that then at length, having got them in their power, they may destroy them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:5
verses.text: Whence we must give no heed to them, but ought rather to confute them when speaking, since we do not need them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:6
verses.text: For what wonder is it, if with more subtle bodies than men have, when they have seen them start on their journey, they surpass them in speed, and announce their coming? Just as a horseman getting a start of a man on foot announces the arrival of the latter beforehand, so in this there is no need for us to wonder at them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:7
verses.text: For they know none of those things which are not yet in existence; but God only is He who knoweth all things before their birth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:8
verses.text: But these, like thieves, running off first with what they see, proclaim it: to how many already have they announced our business—that we are assembled together, and discuss measures against them, before any one of us could go and tell these things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:9
verses.text: This in good truth a fleet-footed boy could do, getting far ahead of one less swift.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:10
verses.text: But what I mean is this.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:11
verses.text: If any one begins to walk from the Thebaid, or from any other district, before he begins to walk, they do not know whether he will walk.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:12
verses.text: But when they have seen him walking they run on, and before he comes up report his approach.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:13
verses.text: And so it falls out that after a few days the travellers arrive.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 31:14
verses.text: But often the walkers turn back, and the demons prove false.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 32:2
verses.text: 'So, too, with respect to the water of the river, they sometimes make foolish statements.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 32:3
verses.text: For having seen that there has been much rain in the regions of Ethiopia, and knowing that they are the cause of the flood of the river before the water has come to Egypt they run on and announce it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 32:4
verses.text: And this men could have told, if they had as great power of running as the demons.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 32:5
verses.text: And as David's spy going up to a lofty place saw the man approaching better than one who stayed down below, and the forerunner himself announced, before the others came up, not those things which had not taken place, but those things which were already on the way and were being accomplished, so these also prefer to labour, and declare what is happening to others simply for the sake of deceiving them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 32:6
verses.text: If, however, Providence meantime plans anything different for the waters or wayfarers—for Providence can do this—the demons are deceived, and those who gave heed to them cheated.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:2
verses.text: 'Thus in days gone by arose the oracles of the Greeks, and thus they were led astray by the demons.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:3
verses.text: But thus also thenceforth their deception was brought to an end by the coming of the Lord, who brought to nought the demons and their devices.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:4
verses.text: For they know nothing of themselves, but, like thieves, what they get to know from others they pass on, and guess at rather than foretell things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:5
verses.text: Therefore if sometimes they speak the truth, let no one marvel at them for this.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:6
verses.text: For experienced physicians also, since they see the same malady in different people, often foretell what it is, making it out by their acquaintance with it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:7
verses.text: Pilots, too, and farmers, from their familiarity with the weather, tell at a glance the state of the atmosphere, and forecast whether it will be stormy or fine.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:8
verses.text: And no one would say that they do this by inspiration, but from experience and practice.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:9
verses.text: So if the demons sometimes do the same by guesswork, let no one wonder at it or heed them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:10
verses.text: For what use to the hearers is it to know from them what is going to happen before the time? Or what concern have we to know such things, even if the knowledge be true? For it is not productive of virtue, nor is it any token of goodness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:11
verses.text: For none of us is judged for what he knows not, and no one is called blessed because he hath learning and knowledge.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 33:12
verses.text: But each one will be called to judgment in these points—whether he have kept the faith and truly observed the commandments.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 34:2
verses.text: 'Wherefore there is no need to set much value on these things, nor for the sake of them to practise a life of discipline and labour; but that living well we may please God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 34:3
verses.text: And we neither ought to pray to know the future, nor to ask for it as the reward of our discipline; but our prayer should be that the Lord may be our fellow-helper for victory over the devil.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 34:4
verses.text: And if even once we have a desire to know the future, let us be pure in mind, for I believe that if a soul is perfectly pure and in its natural state, it is able, being clear-sighted, to see more and further than the demons—for it has the Lord who reveals to it—like the soul of Elisha, which saw what was done by Gehazi, and beheld the hosts standing on its side.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:2
verses.text: 'When, therefore, they come by night to you and wish to tell the future, or say, "we are the angels," give no heed, for they lie.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:3
verses.text: Yea even if they praise your discipline and call you blessed, hear them not, and have no dealings with them; but rather sign yourselves and your houses, and pray, and you shall see them vanish.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:4
verses.text: For they are cowards, and greatly fear the sign of the Lord's Cross, since of a truth in it the Saviour stripped them, and made an example of them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:5
verses.text: But if they shamelessly stand their ground, capering and changing their forms of appearance, fear them not, nor shrink, nor heed them as though they were good spirits.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:6
verses.text: For the presence either of the good or evil by the help of God can easily be distinguished.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:7
verses.text: The vision of the holy ones is not fraught with distraction: "For they will not strive, nor cry, nor shall any one hear their voice".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:8
verses.text: But it comes so quietly and gently that immediately joy, gladness and courage arise in the soul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:9
verses.text: For the Lord who is our joy is with them, and the power of God the Father.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:10
verses.text: And the thoughts of the soul remain unruffled and undisturbed, so that it, enlightened as it were with rays, beholds by itself those who appear.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:11
verses.text: For the love of what is divine and of the things to come possesses it, and willingly it would be wholly joined with them if it could depart along with them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:12
verses.text: But if, being men, some fear the vision of the good, those who appear immediately take fear away; as Gabriel did in the case of Zacharias, and as the angel did who appeared to the women at the holy sepulchre, and as He did who said to the shepherds in the Gospel, "Fear not".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:13
verses.text: For their fear arose not from timidity, but from the recognition of the presence of superior beings.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 35:14
verses.text: Such then is the nature of the visions of the holy ones.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 36:2
verses.text: 'But the inroad and the display of the evil spirits is fraught with confusion, with din, with sounds and cryings such as the disturbance of boorish youths or robbers would occasion.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 36:3
verses.text: From which arise fear in the heart, tumult and confusion of thought, dejection, hatred towards them who live a life of discipline, indifference, grief, remembrance of kinsfolk and fear of death, and finally desire of evil things, disregard of virtue and unsettled habits.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 36:4
verses.text: Whenever, therefore, ye have seen ought and are afraid, if your fear is immediately taken away and in place of it comes joy unspeakable, cheerfulness, courage, renewed strength, calmness of thought and all those I named before, boldness and love toward God,—take courage and pray.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 36:5
verses.text: For joy and a settled state of soul show the holiness of him who is present.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 36:6
verses.text: Thus Abraham beholding the Lord rejoiced; so also John at the voice of Mary, the God-bearer, leaped for gladness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 36:7
verses.text: But if at the appearance of any there is confusion, knocking without, worldly display, threats of death and the other things which I have already mentioned, know ye that it is an onslaught of evil spirits.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 37:2
verses.text: 'And let this also be a token for you: whenever the soul remains fearful there is a presence of the enemies.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 37:3
verses.text: For the demons do not take away the fear of their presence as the great archangel Gabriel did for Mary and Zacharias, and as he did who appeared to the women at the tomb; but rather whenever they see men afraid they increase their delusions that men may be terrified the more; and at last attacking they mock them, saying, "fall down and worship".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 37:4
verses.text: Thus they deceived the Greeks, and thus by them they were considered gods, falsely so called.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 37:5
verses.text: But the Lord did not suffer us to be deceived by the devil, for He rebuked him whenever he framed such delusions against Him, saying: "Get behind me, Satan: for it is written, Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and Him only shalt thou serve".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 37:6
verses.text: More and more, therefore, let the deceiver be despised by us; for what the Lord hath said, this for our sakes He hath done: that the demons hearing like words from us may be put to flight through the Lord who rebuked them in those words.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 38:2
verses.text: 'And it is not fitting to boast at the casting forth of the demons, nor to be uplifted by the healing of diseases: nor is it fitting that he who casts out devils should alone be highly esteemed, while he who casts them not out should be considered nought.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 38:3
verses.text: But let a man learn the discipline of each one and either imitate, rival, or correct it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 38:4
verses.text: For the working of signs is not ours but the Saviour's work: and so He said to His disciples: "Rejoice not that the demons are subject to you, but that your names are written in the heavens".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 38:5
verses.text: For the fact that our names are written in heaven is a proof of our virtuous life, but to cast out demons is a favour of the Saviour who granted it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 38:6
verses.text: Wherefore to those who boasted in signs but not in virtue, and said: "Lord, in Thy name did we not cast out demons, and in Thy name did many mighty works?" He answered, "Verily I say unto you, I know you not;" for the Lord knoweth not the ways of the wicked.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 38:7
verses.text: But we ought always to pray, as I said above, that we may receive the gift of discerning spirits; that, as it is written, we may not believe every spirit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 39:2
verses.text: 'I should have liked to speak no further and to say nothing from my own promptings, satisfied with what I have said: but lest you should think that I speak at random and believe that I detail these things without experience or truth; for this cause even though I should become as a fool, yet the Lord who heareth knoweth the clearness of my conscience, and that it is not for my own sake, but on account of your affection towards me and at your petition that I again tell what I saw of the practices of evil spirits.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 39:3
verses.text: How often have they called me blessed and I have cursed them in the name of the Lord! How often have they predicted the rising of the river, and I answered them, "What have you to do with it?" Once they came threatening and surrounded me like soldiers in full armour.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 39:4
verses.text: At another time they filled the house with horses, wild beasts and creeping things, and I sang: "Some in chariots and some in horses, but we will boast in the name of the Lord our God;" and at the prayers they were turned to flight by the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 39:5
verses.text: Once they came in darkness, bearing the appearance of a light, and said, "We are come to give thee a light, Antony".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 39:6
verses.text: But I closed my eyes and prayed, and immediately the light of the wicked ones was quenched.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 39:7
verses.text: And a few months after they came as though singing psalms and babbling the words of Scripture, "But I like a deaf man, heard not".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 39:8
verses.text: Once they shook the cell with an earthquake, but I continued praying with unshaken heart.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 39:9
verses.text: And after this they came again making noises, whistling and dancing.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 39:10
verses.text: But as I prayed and lay singing psalms to myself they forthwith began to lament and weep, as if their strength had failed them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 39:11
verses.text: But I gave glory to the Lord who had brought down and made an example of their daring and madness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 40:2
verses.text: 'Once a demon exceeding high appeared with pomp, and dared to say, "I am the power of God and I am Providence, what dost thou wish that I shall give thee?" But I then so much the more breathed upon him, and spoke the name of Christ, and set about to smite him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 40:3
verses.text: And I seemed to have smitten him, and forthwith he, big as he was, together with all his demons, disappeared at the name of Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 40:4
verses.text: At another time, while I was fasting, he came full of craft, under the semblance of a monk, with what seemed to be loaves, and gave me counsel, saying, "Eat and cease from thy many labours.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 40:5
verses.text: Thou also art a man and art like to fall sick".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 40:6
verses.text: But I, perceiving his device, rose up to pray; and he endured it not, for he departed, and through the door there seemed to go out as it were smoke.
