verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 40:7
verses.text: How often in the desert has he displayed what resembled gold, that I should only touch it and look on it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 40:8
verses.text: But I sang psalms against him, and he vanished away.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 40:9
verses.text: Often they would beat me with stripes, and I repeated again and again, "Nothing shall separate me from the love of Christ," and at this they rather fell to beating one another.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 40:10
verses.text: Nor was it I that stayed them and destroyed their power, but it was the Lord, who said, "I beheld Satan as lightning fall from Heaven;" but I, children, mindful of the Apostle's words, transferred this to myself, that you might learn not to faint in discipline, nor to fear the devil nor the delusions of the demons.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 41:2
verses.text: 'And since I have become a fool in detailing these things, receive this also as an aid to your safety and fearlessness; and believe me for I do not lie.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 41:3
verses.text: Once some one knocked at the door of my cell, and going forth I saw one who seemed of great size and tall.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 41:4
verses.text: Then when I enquired, "Who art thou?" he said, "I am Satan".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 41:5
verses.text: Then when I said, "Why art thou here?" he answered, "Why do the monks and all other Christians blame me undeservedly? Why do they curse me hourly?" Then I answered, "Wherefore dost thou trouble them?" He said, "I am not he who troubles them, but they trouble themselves, for I am become weak.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 41:6
verses.text: Have they not read," "The swords of the enemy have come to an end, and thou hast destroyed the cities?" "I have no longer a place, a weapon, a city.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 41:7
verses.text: The Christians are spread everywhere, and at length even the desert is filled with monks.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 41:8
verses.text: Let them take heed to themselves, and let them not curse me undeservedly".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 41:9
verses.text: Then I marvelled at the grace of the Lord, and said to him: "Thou who art ever a liar and never speakest the truth, this at length, even against thy will, thou hast truly spoken.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 41:10
verses.text: For the coming of Christ hath made thee weak, and He hath cast thee down and stripped thee".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 41:11
verses.text: But he having heard the Saviour's name, and not being able to bear the burning from it, vanished.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:2
verses.text: 'If, therefore, the devil himself confesses that his power is gone, we ought utterly to despise both him and his demons; and since the enemy with his hounds has but devices of this sort, we, having got to know their weakness, are able to despise them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:3
verses.text: Wherefore let us not despond after this fashion, nor let us have a thought of cowardice in our heart, nor frame fears for ourselves, saying, I am afraid lest a demon should come and overthrow me; lest he should lift me up and cast me down; or lest rising against me on a sudden he confound me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:4
verses.text: Such thoughts let us not have in mind at all, nor let us be sorrowful as though we were perishing; but rather let us be courageous and rejoice always, believing that we are safe.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:5
verses.text: Let us consider in our soul that the Lord is with us, who put the evil spirits to flight and broke their power.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:6
verses.text: Let us consider and lay to heart that while the Lord is with us, our foes can do us no hurt.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:7
verses.text: For when they come they approach us in a form corresponding to the state in which they discover us, and adapt their delusions to the condition of mind in which they find us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:8
verses.text: If, therefore, they find us timid and confused, they forthwith beset the place, like robbers, having found it unguarded; and what we of ourselves are thinking, they do, and more also.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:9
verses.text: For if they find us faint-hearted and cowardly, they mightily increase our terror, by their delusions and threats; and with these the unhappy soul is thenceforth tormented.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:10
verses.text: But if they see us rejoicing in the Lord, contemplating the bliss of the future, mindful of the Lord, deeming all things in His hand, and that no evil spirit has any strength against the Christian, nor any power at all over any one—when they behold the soul fortified with these thoughts—they are discomfited and turned backwards.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:11
verses.text: Thus the enemy, seeing Job fenced round with them, withdrew from him; but finding Judas unguarded, him he took captive.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:12
verses.text: Thus if we are wishful to despise the enemy, let us ever ponder over the things of the Lord, and let the soul ever rejoice in hope.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:13
verses.text: And we shall see the snares of the demon are like smoke, and the evil ones themselves flee rather than pursue.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 42:14
verses.text: For they are, as I said before, exceeding fearful, ever looking forward to the fire prepared for them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 43:2
verses.text: 'And for your fearlessness against them hold this sure sign—whenever there is any apparition, be not prostrate with fear, but whatsoever it be, first boldly ask, Who art thou? And from whence comest thou? And if it should be a vision of holy ones they will assure you, and change your fear into joy.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 43:3
verses.text: But if the vision should be from the devil, immediately it becomes feeble, beholding your firm purpose of mind.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 43:4
verses.text: For merely to ask, Who art thou? and whence comest thou? is a proof of coolness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 43:5
verses.text: By thus asking, the son of Nun learned who his helper was; nor did the enemy escape the questioning of Daniel.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 44:2
verses.text: While Antony was thus speaking all rejoiced; in some the love of virtue increased, in others carelessness was thrown aside, the self-conceit of others was stopped; and all were persuaded to despise the assaults of the Evil One, and marvelled at the grace given to Antony from the Lord for the discerning of spirits.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 44:3
verses.text: So their cells were in the mountains, like filled with holy bands of men who sang psalms, loved reading, fasted, prayed, rejoiced in the hope of things to come, laboured in alms-giving, and preserved love and harmony one with another.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 44:4
verses.text: And truly it was possible, as it were, to behold a land set by itself, filled with piety and justice.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 44:5
verses.text: For then there was neither the evil-doer, nor the injured, nor the reproaches of the tax-gatherer: but instead a multitude of ascetics; and the one purpose of them all was to aim at virtue.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 44:6
verses.text: So that any one beholding the cells again, and seeing such good order among the monks, would lift up his voice and say, 'How goodly are thy dwellings, O Jacob, and thy tents, O Israel; as shady glens and as a garden by a river; as tents which the Lord hath pitched, and like cedars near waters.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 45:2
verses.text: Antony, however, according to his custom, returned alone to his own cell, increased his discipline, and sighed daily as he thought of the mansions in Heaven, having his desire fixed on them, and pondering over the shortness of man's life.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 45:3
verses.text: And he used to eat and sleep, and go about all other bodily necessities with shame when he thought of the spiritual faculties of the soul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 45:4
verses.text: So often, when about to eat with any other hermits, recollecting the spiritual food, he begged to be excused, and departed far off from them, deeming it a matter for shame if he should be seen eating by others.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 45:5
verses.text: He used, however, when by himself, to eat through bodily necessity, but often also with the brethren; covered with shame on these occasions, yet speaking boldly words of help.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 45:6
verses.text: And he used to say that it behoved a man to give all his time to his soul rather than his body, yet to grant a short space to the body through its necessities; but all the more earnestly to give up the whole remainder to the soul and seek its profit, that it might not be dragged down by the pleasures of the body, but, on the contrary, the body might be in subjection to the soul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 45:7
verses.text: For this is that which was spoken by the Saviour: 'Be not anxious for your life what ye shall eat, nor for your body what ye shall put on.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 45:8
verses.text: And do ye seek not what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink, and be not of a doubtful mind.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 45:9
verses.text: For all these things the nations of the world seek after.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 45:10
verses.text: But your Father knoweth that ye have need of all these things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 45:11
verses.text: Howbeit seek ye first His Kingdom, and all these things shall be added unto you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 46:2
verses.text: After this the Church was seized by the persecution which then took place under Maximinus, and when the holy martyrs were led to Alexandria, Antony also followed, leaving his cell, and saying, Let us go too, that if called, we may contend or behold them that are contending.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 46:3
verses.text: And he longed to suffer martyrdom, but not being willing to give himself up, he ministered to the confessors in the mines and in the prisons.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 46:4
verses.text: And he was very zealous in the judgment hall to stir up to readiness those who were summoned when in their contest, while those who were being martyred he received and brought on their way until they were perfected.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 46:5
verses.text: The judge, therefore, beholding the fearlessness of Antony and his companions, and their zeal in this matter, commanded that no monk should appear in the judgment hall, nor remain at all in the city.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 46:6
verses.text: So all the rest thought it good to hide themselves that day, but Antony gave so little heed to the command that he washed his garment, and stood all next day on a raised place before them, and appeared in his best before the governor.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 46:7
verses.text: Therefore when all the rest wondered at this, and the governor saw and passed by with his array, he stood fearlessly, shewing the readiness of us Christians.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 46:8
verses.text: For, as I said before, he prayed himself to be a martyr, wherefore he seemed as one grieved that he had not borne his witness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 46:9
verses.text: But the Lord was keeping him for our profit and that of others, that he should become a teacher to many of the discipline which he had learned from the Scriptures.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 46:10
verses.text: For many only beholding his manner of life were eager to be imitators of his ways.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 46:11
verses.text: So he again ministered as usual to the confessors, and as though he were their fellow captive he laboured in his ministry.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 47:2
verses.text: And when at last the persecution ceased, and the blessed Bishop Peter had borne his testimony, Antony departed, and again withdrew to his cell, and was there daily a martyr to his conscience, and contending in the conflicts of faith.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 47:3
verses.text: And his discipline was much severer, for he was ever fasting, and he had a garment of hair on the inside, while the outside was skin, which he kept until his end.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 47:4
verses.text: And he neither bathed his body with water to free himself from filth, nor did he ever wash his feet, nor even endure so much as to put them into water, unless compelled by necessity.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 47:5
verses.text: Nor did any one even see him unclothed, nor his body naked at all, except after his death, when he was buried.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 48:2
verses.text: When therefore he had retired and determined to fix a time, after which neither to go forth himself nor admit anybody, Martinian, a military officer, came and disturbed Antony.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 48:3
verses.text: For he had a daughter afflicted with an evil spirit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 48:4
verses.text: But when he continued for a long while knocking at the door, and asking him to come out and pray to God for his child, Antony, not bearing to open, looked out from above and said, 'Man, why dost thou call on me? I also am a man even as you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 48:5
verses.text: But if you believe on Christ whom I serve, go, and according as you believe, pray to God, and it shall come to pass.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 48:6
verses.text: ' Straightway, therefore, he departed, believing and calling upon Christ, and he received his daughter cleansed from the devil.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 48:7
verses.text: Many other things also through Antony the Lord did, who saith, 'Seek and it shall be given unto you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 48:8
verses.text: ' For many of the sufferers, when he would not open his door, slept outside his cell, and by their faith and sincere prayers were healed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 49:2
verses.text: But when he saw himself beset by many, and not suffered to withdraw himself according to his intent as he wished, fearing because of the signs which the Lord wrought by him, that either he should be puffed up, or that some other should think of him above what he ought to think, he considered and set off to go into the upper Thebaid, among those to whom he was unknown.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 49:3
verses.text: And having received loaves from the brethren, he sat down by the bank of the river, looking whether a boat would go by, that, having embarked thereon, he might go up the river with them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 49:4
verses.text: While he was considering these things, a voice came to him from above, 'Antony, whither goest thou and wherefore?' But he no way disturbed, but as he had been accustomed to be called often thus, giving ear to it, answered, saying, 'Since the multitude permit me not to be still, I wish to go into the upper Thebaid on account of the many hindrances that come upon me here, and especially because they demand of me things beyond my power.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 49:5
verses.text: ' But the voice said unto him, 'Even though you should go into the Thebaid, or even though, as you have in mind, you should go down to the Bucolia, you will have to endure more, aye, double the amount of toil.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 49:6
verses.text: But if you wish really to be in quiet, depart now into the inner desert.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 49:7
verses.text: ' And when Antony said, 'Who will show me the way for I know it not?' immediately the voice pointed out to him Saracens about to go that way.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 49:8
verses.text: So Antony approached, and drew near them, and asked that he might go with them into the desert.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 49:9
verses.text: And they, as though they had been commanded by Providence, received him willingly.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 49:10
verses.text: And having journeyed with them three days and three nights, he came to a very lofty mountain, and at the foot of the mountain ran a clear spring, whose waters were sweet and very cold; outside there was a plain and a few uncared-for palm trees.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:2
verses.text: Antony then, as it were, moved by God, loved the place, for this was the spot which he who had spoken with him by the banks of the river had pointed out.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:3
verses.text: So having first received loaves from his fellow travellers, he abode in the mountain alone, no one else being with him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:4
verses.text: And recognising it as his own home, he remained in that place for the future.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:5
verses.text: But the Saracens, having seen the earnestness of Antony, purposely used to journey that way, and joyfully brought him loaves, while now and then the palm trees also afforded him a poor and frugal relish.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:6
verses.text: But after this, the brethren learning of the place, like children mindful of their father, took care to send to him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:7
verses.text: But when Antony saw that the bread was the cause of trouble and hardships to some of them, to spare the monks this, he resolved to ask some of those who came to bring him a spade, an axe, and a little corn.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:8
verses.text: And when these were brought, he went over the land round the mountain, and having found a small plot of suitable ground, tilled it; and having a plentiful supply of water for watering, he sowed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:9
verses.text: This doing year by year, he got his bread from thence, rejoicing that thus he would be troublesome to no one, and because he kept himself from being a burden to anybody.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:10
verses.text: But after this, seeing again that people came, he cultivated a few pot-herbs, that he who came to him might have some slight solace after the labour of that hard journey.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:11
verses.text: At first, however, the wild beasts in the desert, coming because of the water, often injured his seeds and husbandry.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:12
verses.text: But he, gently laying hold of one of them, said to them all, 'Why do you hurt me, when I hurt none of you? Depart, and in the name of the Lord come not nigh this spot.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 50:13
verses.text: ' And from that time forward, as though fearful of his command, they no more came near the place.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 51:2
verses.text: So he was alone in the inner mountain, spending his time in prayer and discipline.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 51:3
verses.text: And the brethren who served him asked that they might come every month and bring him olives, pulse and oil, for by now he was an old man.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 51:4
verses.text: There then he passed his life, and endured such great wrestlings, 'Not against flesh and blood,' as it is written, but against opposing demons, as we learned from those who visited him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 51:5
verses.text: For there they heard tumults, many voices, and, as it were, the clash of arms.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 51:6
verses.text: At night they saw the mountain become full of wild beasts, and him also fighting as though against visible beings, and praying against them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 51:7
verses.text: And those who came to him he encouraged, while kneeling he contended and prayed to the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 51:8
verses.text: Surely it was a marvellous thing that a man, alone in such a desert, feared neither the demons who rose up against him, nor the fierceness of the four-footed beasts and creeping things, for all they were so many.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 51:9
verses.text: But in truth, as it is written, 'He trusted in the Lord as Mount Sion,' with a mind unshaken and undisturbed; so that the demons rather fled from him, and the wild beasts, as it is written, 'kept peace with him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 52:2
verses.text: The devil, therefore, as David says in the Psalms, observed Antony and gnashed his teeth against him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 52:3
verses.text: But Antony was consoled by the Saviour and continued unhurt by his wiles and varied devices.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 52:4
verses.text: As he was watching in the night the devil sent wild beasts against him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 52:5
verses.text: And almost all the hyenas in that desert came forth from their dens and surrounded him; and he was in the midst, while each one threatened to bite.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 52:6
verses.text: Seeing that it was a trick of the enemy he said to them all: 'If ye have received power against me I am ready to be devoured by you; but if ye were sent against me by demons, stay not, but depart, for I am a servant of Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 52:7
verses.text: ' When Antony said this they fled, driven by that word as with a whip.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 53:2
verses.text: A few days after, as he was working (for he was careful to work hard), some one stood at the door and pulled the plait which he was working, for he used to weave baskets, which he gave to those who came in return for what they brought him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 53:3
verses.text: And rising up he saw a beast like a man to the thighs but having legs and feet like those of an ass.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 53:4
verses.text: And Antony only signed himself and said, 'I am a servant of Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 53:5
verses.text: If thou art sent against me, behold I am here.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 53:6
verses.text: ' But the beast together with his evil spirits fled, so that, through his speed, he fell and died.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 53:7
verses.text: And the death of the beast was the fall of the demons.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 53:8
verses.text: For they strove in all manner of ways to lead Antony from the desert and were not able.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:2
verses.text: And once being asked by the monks to come down and visit them and their abodes after a time, he journeyed with those who came to him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:3
verses.text: And a camel carried the loaves and the water for them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:4
verses.text: For all that desert is dry, and there is no water at all that is fit to drink, save in that mountain from whence they drew the water, and in which Antony's cell was.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:5
verses.text: So when the water failed them on their way, and the heat was very great, they all were in danger.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:6
verses.text: For having gone round the neighbourhood and finding no water, they could walk no further, but lay on the ground and despairing of themselves, let the camel go.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:7
verses.text: But the old man seeing that they were all in jeopardy, groaning in deep grief, departed a little way from them, and kneeling down he stretched forth his hands and prayed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:8
verses.text: And immediately the Lord made water to well forth where he had stood praying, and so all drank and were revived.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:9
verses.text: And having filled their bottles they sought the camel and found her, for the rope happened to have caught in a stone and so was held fast.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:10
verses.text: Having led it and watered it they placed the bottles on its back and finished their journey in safety.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:11
verses.text: And when he came to the outer cells all saluted him, looking on him as a father.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:12
verses.text: And he too, as though bringing supplies from the mountain, entertained them with his words and gave them a share of help.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:13
verses.text: And again there was joy in the mountains, zeal for improvement and consolation through their mutual faith.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 54:14
verses.text: Antony also rejoiced when he beheld the earnestness of the monks, and his sister grown old in virginity, and that she herself also was the leader of other virgins.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:2
verses.text: So after certain days he went in again to the mountain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:3
verses.text: And henceforth many resorted to him, and others who were suffering ventured to go in.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:4
verses.text: To all the monks therefore who came to him, he continually gave this precept: 'Believe on the Lord and love Him; keep yourselves from filthy thoughts and fleshly pleasures, and as it is written in the Proverbs, be not deceived "by the fulness of the belly".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:5
verses.text: Pray continually; avoid vainglory; sing psalms before sleep and on awaking; hold in your heart the commandments of Scripture; be mindful of the works of the saints that your souls being put in remembrance of the commandments may be brought into harmony with the zeal of the saints.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:6
verses.text: ' And especially he counselled them to meditate continually on the apostle's word, 'Let not the sun go down upon your wrath.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:7
verses.text: ' And he considered this was spoken of all commandments in common, and that not on wrath alone, but not on any other sin of ours, ought the sun to go down.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:8
verses.text: For it was good and needful that neither the sun should condemn us for an evil by day nor the moon for a sin by night, or even for an evil thought.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:9
verses.text: That this state may be preserved in us it is good to hear the apostle and keep his words, for he says, 'Try your own selves and prove your own selves.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:10
verses.text: ' Daily, therefore, let each one take from himself the tale of his actions both by day and night; and if he have sinned, let him cease from it; while if he have not, let him not be boastful.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:11
verses.text: But let him abide in that which is good, without being negligent, nor condemning his neighbours, nor justifying himself, 'until the Lord come who searcheth out hidden things,' as saith the blessed apostle Paul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:12
verses.text: For often unawares we do things that we know not of; but the Lord seeth all things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:13
verses.text: Wherefore committing the judgment to Him, let us have sympathy one with another.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:14
verses.text: Let us bear each other's burdens: but let us examine our own selves and hasten to fill up that in which we are lacking.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:15
verses.text: And as a safeguard against sin let the following be observed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:16
verses.text: Let us each one note and write down our actions and the impulses of our soul as though we were going to relate them to each other.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:17
verses.text: And be assured that if we should be utterly ashamed to have them known, we shall abstain from sin and harbour no base thoughts in our mind.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:18
verses.text: For who wishes to be seen while sinning? or who will not rather lie after the commission of a sin, through the wish to escape notice? As then while we are looking at one another, we would not commit carnal sin, so if we record our thoughts as though about to tell them to one another, we shall the more easily keep ourselves free from vile thoughts through shame lest they should be known.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:19
verses.text: Wherefore let that which is written be to us in place of the eyes of our fellow hermits, that blushing as much to write as if we had been caught, we may never think of what is unseemly.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 55:20
verses.text: Thus fashioning ourselves we shall be able to keep the body in subjection, to please the Lord, and to trample on the devices of the enemy.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 56:2
verses.text: This was the advice he gave to those who came to him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 56:3
verses.text: And with those who suffered he sympathised and prayed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 56:4
verses.text: And oft-times the Lord heard him on behalf of many: yet he boasted not because he was heard, nor did he murmur if he were not.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 56:5
verses.text: But always he gave the Lord thanks and besought the sufferer to be patient, and to know that healing belonged neither to him nor to man at all, but only to the Lord, who doeth good when and to whom He will.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 56:6
verses.text: The sufferers therefore used to receive the words of the old man as though they were a cure, learning not to be downhearted but rather to be long-suffering.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 56:7
verses.text: And those who were healed were taught not to give thanks to Antony but to God alone.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 57:2
verses.text: Wherefore a man, Fronto by name, who was an officer of the Court and had a terrible disease, for he used to bite his own tongue and was in danger of injury to his eyes, having come to the mountain, asked Antony to pray for him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 57:3
verses.text: But Antony said to him, 'Depart and thou shalt be healed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 57:4
verses.text: ' But when he was violent and remained within some days, Antony waited and said, 'If thou stayest here, thou canst not be healed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 57:5
verses.text: Go, and having come into Egypt thou shalt see the sign wrought in thee.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 57:6
verses.text: ' And he believed and went.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 57:7
verses.text: And as soon as he set eyes on Egypt his sufferings ceased, and the man became whole according to the word of Antony, which the Saviour had revealed to him in prayer.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 58:2
verses.text: There was also a maiden from Busiris Tripolitana, who had a terrible and very hideous disorder.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 58:3
verses.text: For the runnings of her eyes, nose, and ears fell to the ground and immediately became worms.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 58:4
verses.text: She was paralysed also and squinted.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 58:5
verses.text: Her parents having heard of monks going to Antony, and believing on the Lord who healed the woman with the issue of blood, asked to be allowed, together with their daughter, to journey with them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 58:6
verses.text: And when they suffered them, the parents together with the girl, remained outside the mountain with Paphnutius, the confessor and monk; but the monks went in to Antony.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 58:7
verses.text: And when they only wished to tell about the damsel, he anticipated them, and detailed both the sufferings of the child and how she journeyed with them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 58:8
verses.text: Then when they asked that she should be admitted, Antony did not allow it, but said, 'Go, and if she be not dead, you will find her healed: for the accomplishment of this is not mine, that she should come to me, wretched man that I am, but her healing is the work of the Saviour, who in every place sheweth His pity to them that call upon Him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 58:9
verses.text: Wherefore the Lord hath inclined to her as she prayed, and His loving-kindness hath declared to me that He will heal the child where she now is.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 58:10
verses.text: ' So the wonder took place; and going out they found the parents rejoicing and the girl whole.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 59:2
verses.text: But when two brethren were coming to him, the water failed on the way, and one died and the other was at the point of death, for he had no strength to go on, but lay upon the ground expecting to die.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 59:3
verses.text: But Antony sitting in the mountain called two monks, who chanced to be there, and urged them saying, 'Take a pitcher of water and run on the road towards Egypt.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 59:4
verses.text: For of two men who were coming, one is already dead and the other will die unless you hasten.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 59:5
verses.text: For this has been revealed to me as I was praying.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 59:6
verses.text: ' The monks therefore went, and found one lying dead, whom they buried, and the other they restored with water and led him to the old man.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 59:7
verses.text: For it was a day's journey.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 59:8
verses.text: But if any one asks, why he did not speak before the other died, the question ought not to be asked.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 59:9
verses.text: For the punishment of death was not Antony's but God's, who also judged the one and revealed the condition of the other.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 59:10
verses.text: But the marvel here was only in the case of Antony: that he sitting in the mountain had his heart watchful, and had the Lord to show him things afar off.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:2
verses.text: And this is so, for once again he was sitting on the mountain, and looking up saw in the air some one being borne upwards, and there was much joy among those who met him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:3
verses.text: Then wondering and deeming a company of that kind to be blessed, he prayed to learn what this might be.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:4
verses.text: And immediately a voice came to him: 'This is the soul of Amun, the monk at Nitria.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:5
verses.text: ' Now Amun had persevered in the discipline up to old age; and the distance from Nitria to the mountain where Antony was, was thirteen days' journey.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:6
verses.text: The companions of Antony therefore, seeing the old man amazed, asked to learn, and heard that Amun was just dead.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:7
verses.text: And he was well known, for he had stayed there very often, and many signs had been wrought by his means.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:8
verses.text: And this is one of them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:9
verses.text: Once when he had need to cross the river called Lycus (now it was the season of the flood), he asked his comrade Theodorus to remain at a distance, that they should not see one another naked as they swam the water.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:10
verses.text: Then when Theodorus was departed he again felt ashamed even to see himself naked.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:11
verses.text: While, therefore, he was pondering filled with shame, on a sudden he was borne over to the other side.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:12
verses.text: Theodorus, therefore, himself being a good man, approached, and seeing Amun across first without a drop of water falling from him, enquired how he had got over.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:13
verses.text: And when he saw that Amun was unwilling to tell him, he held him by the feet and declared that he would not let him go before he had learned it from him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:14
verses.text: So Amun seeing the determination of Theodorus especially from what he had said, and having asked him to tell no man before his death, told him that he had been carried and placed on the further side.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:15
verses.text: And that he had not even set foot on the water, nor was that possible for man, but for the Lord alone and those whom He permits, as He did for the great apostle Peter.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:16
verses.text: Theodorus therefore told this after the death of Amun.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:17
verses.text: And the monks to whom Antony spoke concerning Amun's death marked the day; and when the brethren came up from Nitria thirty days after, they enquired of them and learned that Amun had fallen asleep at that day and hour in which the old man had seen his soul borne upwards.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 60:18
verses.text: And both these and the others marvelled at the purity of Antony's soul, how he had immediately learned that which was taking place at a distance of thirteen days' journey, and had seen the soul as it was taken up.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 61:2
verses.text: And Archelaus too, the Count, on a time having found him in the outer mountain, asked him merely to pray for Polycratia of Laodicea, an excellent and Christian maiden, for she suffered terribly in the stomach and side through over much discipline, and was altogether weakly of body.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 61:3
verses.text: Antony prayed therefore, and the Count noted the day in which the prayer was made, and having departed to Laodicea he found the maiden whole.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 61:4
verses.text: And having enquired when and on what day she was relieved of her infirmity, he produced the paper on which he had written the time of the prayer, and having read it he immediately shewed the writing on the paper.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 61:5
verses.text: And all wondered when they knew that the Lord had relieved her of pain at the time when Antony was praying and invoking the goodness of the Saviour on her behalf.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 62:2
verses.text: And concerning those who came to him, he often foretold some days or sometimes a month beforehand what was the cause of their coming.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 62:3
verses.text: For some came only for the sake of seeing him, others through sickness, and others suffering from evil spirits.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 62:4
verses.text: And all thought the labour of the journey neither trouble nor loss.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 62:5
verses.text: For each one returned aware that he had received benefit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 62:6
verses.text: But though saying such things and beholding such sights, he used to ask that no one should wonder at him for this; but should rather marvel at the Lord for having granted to us men to know Him as far as our powers extended.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 63:2
verses.text: Afterwards, on another occasion, having descended to the outer cells, he was asked to enter a vessel and pray with the monks, and he alone perceived an exceedingly unpleasant smell.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 63:3
verses.text: But those on board said that the stench arose from the fish and salt meat in the ship.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 63:4
verses.text: He replied however, the smell was different from that; and while he was speaking, a youth with an evil spirit, who had come and hidden himself in the ship, cried out.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 63:5
verses.text: But the demon being rebuked in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ departed from him, and the man became whole.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 63:6
verses.text: And all knew that the evil smell arose from the demon.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 64:2
verses.text: And another, a person of rank, came to him, possessed by a demon; and the demon was so terrible that the man possessed did not know that he was coming to Antony.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 64:3
verses.text: But he even ate the excreta from his body.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 64:4
verses.text: So those who brought him besought Antony to pray for him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 64:5
verses.text: And Antony pitying the young man prayed and kept watch with him all the night.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 64:6
verses.text: And about dawn the young man suddenly attacked Antony and gave him a push.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 64:7
verses.text: But when those who came with him were angry, Antony said, 'Be not angry with the young man, for it is not he, but the demon which is in him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 64:8
verses.text: And being rebuked and commanded to go into dry places, the demon became raging mad, and he has done this.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 64:9
verses.text: Wherefore give thanks to the Lord, for his attack on me thus is a sign of the departure of the evil spirit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 64:10
verses.text: ' When Antony had said this, straightway the young man had become whole, and having come at last to his right mind, knew where he was, and saluted the old man and gave thanks to God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:2
verses.text: And many monks have related with the greatest agreement and unanimity that many other such like things were done by him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:3
verses.text: But still these do not seem as marvellous as certain other things appear to be.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:4
verses.text: For once, when about to eat, having risen up to pray about the ninth hour, he perceived that he was caught up in the spirit, and, wonderful to tell, he stood and saw himself, as it were, from outside himself, and that he was led in the air by certain ones.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:5
verses.text: Next certain bitter and terrible beings stood in the air and wished to hinder him from passing through.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:6
verses.text: But when his conductors opposed them, they demanded whether he was not accountable to them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:7
verses.text: And when they wished to sum up the account from his birth, Antony's conductors stopped them, saying, 'The Lord hath wiped out the sins from his birth, but from the time he became a monk, and devoted himself to God, it is permitted you to make a reckoning.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:8
verses.text: ' Then when they accused him and could not convict him, his way was free and unhindered.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:9
verses.text: And immediately he saw himself, as it were, coming and standing by himself, and again he was Antony as before.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:10
verses.text: Then forgetful of eating, he remained the rest of the day and through the whole of the night groaning and praying.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:11
verses.text: For he was astonished when he saw against what mighty opponents our wrestling is, and by what labours we have to pass through the air.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:12
verses.text: And he remembered that this is what the Apostle said, 'according to the prince of the power of the air.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:13
verses.text: ' For in it the enemy hath power to fight and to attempt to hinder those who pass through.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:14
verses.text: Wherefore most earnestly he exhorted, 'Take up the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day,' that the enemy, 'having no evil thing to say against us, may be ashamed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:15
verses.text: ' And we who have learned this, let us be mindful of the Apostle when he says, 'whether in the body I know not, or whether out of the body I know not; God knoweth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 65:16
verses.text: ' But Paul was caught up unto the third heaven, and having heard things unspeakable he came down; while Antony saw that he had come to the air, and contended until he was free.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:2
verses.text: And he had also this favour granted him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:3
verses.text: For as he was sitting alone on the mountain, if ever he was in perplexity in his meditations, this was revealed to him by Providence in prayer.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:4
verses.text: And the happy man, as it is written, was taught of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:5
verses.text: After this, when he once had a discussion with certain men who had come to him concerning the state of the soul and of what nature its place will be after this life, the following night one from above called him, saying, 'Antony, rise, go out and look.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:6
verses.text: ' Having gone out therefore (for he knew whom he ought to obey) looking up, he beheld one standing and reaching to the clouds, tall, hideous, and fearful, and others ascending as though they were winged.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:7
verses.text: And the figure stretched forth his hands, and some of those who were ascending were stayed by him, while others flew above, and having escaped heaven-ward, were borne aloft free from care.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:8
verses.text: At such, therefore, the giant gnashed his teeth, but rejoiced over those who fell back.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:9
verses.text: And forthwith a voice came to Antony, 'Understandest thou what thou seest?' And his understanding was opened, and he understood that it was the passing of souls, and that the tall being who stood was the enemy who envies the faithful.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:10
verses.text: And those whom he caught and stopped from passing through are accountable to him, while those whom he was unable to hold as they passed upwards had not been subservient to him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:11
verses.text: So having seen this, and as it were being reminded, he struggled the more daily to advance towards those things which were before.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:12
verses.text: And these visions he was unwilling to tell, but as he spent much time in prayer, and was amazed, when those who were with him pressed him with questions and forced him, he was compelled to speak, as a father who cannot withhold ought from his children.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 66:13
verses.text: And he thought that as his conscience was clear, the account would be beneficial for them, that they might learn that discipline bore good fruit, and that visions were oftentimes the solace of their labours.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:2
verses.text: Added to this he was tolerant in disposition and humble in spirit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:3
verses.text: For though he was such a man, he observed the rule of the Church most rigidly, and was willing that all the clergy should be honoured above himself.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:4
verses.text: For he was not ashamed to bow his head to bishops and presbyters, and if ever a deacon came to him for help he discoursed with him on what was profitable, but gave place to him in prayer, not being ashamed to learn himself.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:5
verses.text: For often he would ask questions, and desired to listen to those who were present, and if any one said anything that was useful he confessed that he was profited.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:6
verses.text: And besides, his countenance had a great and wonderful grace.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:7
verses.text: This gift also he had from the Saviour.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:8
verses.text: For if he were present in a great company of monks, and any one who did not know him previously, wished to see him, immediately coming forward he passed by the rest, and hurried to Antony, as though attracted by his appearance.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:9
verses.text: Yet neither in height nor breadth was he conspicuous above others, but in the serenity of his manner and the purity of his soul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:10
verses.text: For as his soul was free from disturbances, his outward appearance was calm; so from the joy of his soul he possessed a cheerful countenance, and from his bodily movements could be perceived the condition of his soul, as it is written, 'When the heart is merry the countenance is cheerful, but when it is sorrowful it is cast down.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:11
verses.text: ' Thus Jacob recognised the counsel Laban had in his heart, and said to his wives, 'The countenance of your father is not as it was yesterday and the day before.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:12
verses.text: ' Thus Samuel recognised David, for he had mirthful eyes, and teeth white as milk.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 67:13
verses.text: Thus Antony was recognised, for he was never disturbed, for his soul was at peace; he was never downcast, for his mind was joyous.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 68:2
verses.text: And he was altogether wonderful in faith and religious, for he never held communion with the Meletian schismatics, knowing their wickedness and apostacy from the beginning; nor had he friendly dealings with the Manichaeans or any other heretics; or, if he had, only as far as advice that they should change to piety.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 68:3
verses.text: For he thought and asserted that intercourse with these was harmful and destructive to the soul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 68:4
verses.text: In the same manner also he loathed the heresy of the Arians, and exhorted all neither to approach them nor to hold their erroneous belief.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 68:5
verses.text: And once when certain Arian madmen came to him, when he had questioned them and learned their impiety, he drove them from the mountain, saying that their words were worse than the poison of serpents.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 69:2
verses.text: And once also the Arians having lyingly asserted that Antony's opinions were the same as theirs, he was displeased and wroth against them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 69:3
verses.text: Then being summoned by the bishops and all the brethren, he descended from the mountain, and having entered Alexandria, he denounced the Arians, saying that their heresy was the last of all and a forerunner of Antichrist.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 69:4
verses.text: And he taught the people that the Son of God was not a created being, neither had He come into being from non-existence, but that He was the Eternal Word and Wisdom of the Essence of the Father.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 69:5
verses.text: And therefore it was impious to say, 'there was a time when He was not,' for the Word was always co-existent with the Father.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 69:6
verses.text: Wherefore have no fellowship with the most impious Arians.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 69:7
verses.text: For there is no communion between light and darkness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 69:8
verses.text: For you are good Christians, but they, when they say that the Son of the Father, the Word of God, is a created being, differ in nought from the heathen, since they worship that which is created, rather than God the creator.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 69:9
verses.text: But believe ye that the Creation itself is angry with them because they number the Creator, the Lord of all, by whom all things came into being, with those things which were originated.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 70:2
verses.text: All the people, therefore, rejoiced when they heard the anti-Christian heresy anathematised by such a man.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 70:3
verses.text: And all the people in the city ran together to see Antony; and the Greeks and those who are called their Priests, came into the church, saying, 'We ask to see the man of God,' for so they all called him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 70:4
verses.text: For in that place also the Lord cleansed many of demons, and healed those who were mad.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 70:5
verses.text: And many Greeks asked that they might even but touch the old man, believing that they should be profited.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 70:6
verses.text: Assuredly as many became Christians in those few days as one would have seen made in a year.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 70:7
verses.text: Then when some thought that he was troubled by the crowds, and on this account turned them all away from him, he said, undisturbedly, that there were not more of them than of the demons with whom he wrestled in the mountain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 71:2
verses.text: But when he was departing, and we were setting him forth on his way, as we arrived at the gate a woman from behind cried out, 'Stay, thou man of God, my daughter is grievously vexed by a devil.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 71:3
verses.text: Stay, I beseech thee, lest I too harm myself with running.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 71:4
verses.text: ' And the old man when he heard her, and was asked by us, willingly stayed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 71:5
verses.text: And when the woman drew near, the child was cast on the ground.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 71:6
verses.text: But when Antony had prayed and called upon the name of Christ, the child was raised whole, for the unclean spirit was gone forth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 71:7
verses.text: And the mother blessed God, and all gave thanks.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 71:8
verses.text: And Antony himself also rejoiced, departing to the mountain as though it were to his own home.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 72:2
verses.text: And Antony also was exceeding prudent, and the wonder was that although he had not learned letters, he was a ready-witted and sagacious man.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 72:3
verses.text: At all events two Greek philosophers once came, thinking they could try their skill on Antony; and he was in the outer mountain, and having recognised who they were from their appearance, he came to them and said to them by means of an interpreter, 'Why, philosophers, did ye trouble yourselves so much to come to a foolish man?' And when they said that he was not a foolish man, but exceedingly prudent, he said to them, 'If you came to a foolish man, your labour is superfluous; but if you think me prudent become as I am, for we ought to imitate what is good.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 72:4
verses.text: And if I had come to you I should have imitated you; but if you to me, become as I am, for I am a Christian.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 72:5
verses.text: ' But they departed with wonder, for they saw that even demons feared Antony.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 73:2
verses.text: And again others such as these met him in the outer mountain and thought to mock him because he had not learned letters.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 73:3
verses.text: And Antony said to them, 'What say ye? which is first, mind or letters? And which is the cause of which—mind of letters or letters of mind?' And when they answered mind is first and the inventor of letters, Antony said, 'Whoever, therefore, hath a sound mind hath not need of letters.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 73:4
verses.text: ' This answer amazed both the bystanders and the philosophers, and they departed marvelling that they had seen so much understanding in an ignorant man.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 73:5
verses.text: For his manners were not rough as though he had been reared in the mountain and there grown old, but graceful and polite, and his speech was seasoned with the divine salt, so that no one was envious, but rather all rejoiced over him who visited him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 74:2
verses.text: After this again certain others came; and these were men who were deemed wise among the Greeks, and they asked him a reason for our faith in Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 74:3
verses.text: But when they attempted to dispute concerning the preaching of the divine Cross and meant to mock, Antony stopped for a little, and first pitying their ignorance, said, through an interpreter, who could skilfully interpret his words, 'Which is more beautiful, to confess the Cross or to attribute to those whom you call gods adultery and the seduction of boys? For that which is chosen by us is a sign of courage and a sure token of the contempt of death, while yours are the passions of licentiousness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 74:4
verses.text: Next, which is better, to say that the Word of God was not changed, but, being the same, He took a human body for the salvation and well-being of man, that having shared in human birth He might make man partake in the divine and spiritual nature; or to liken the divine to senseless animals and consequently to worship four-footed beasts, creeping things and the likenesses of men? For these things, are the objects of reverence of you wise men.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 74:5
verses.text: But how do you dare to mock us, who say that Christ has appeared as man, seeing that you, bringing the soul from heaven, assert that it has strayed and fallen from the vault of the sky into body? And would that you had said that it had fallen into human body alone, and not asserted that it passes and changes into four-footed beasts and creeping things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 74:6
verses.text: For our faith declares that the coming of Christ was for the salvation of men.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 74:7
verses.text: But you err because you speak of soul as not generated.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 74:8
verses.text: And we, considering the power and loving-kindness of Providence, think that the coming of Christ in the flesh was not impossible with God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 74:9
verses.text: But you, although calling the soul the likeness of Mind, connect it with falls and feign in your myths that it is changeable, and consequently introduce the idea that Mind itself is changeable by reason of the soul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 74:10
verses.text: For whatever is the nature of a likeness, such necessarily is the nature of that of which it is a likeness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 74:11
verses.text: But whenever you think such a thought concerning Mind, remember that you blaspheme even the Father of Mind Himself.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 75:2
verses.text: But concerning the Cross, which would you say to be the better, to bear it, when a plot is brought about by wicked men, nor to be in fear of death brought about under any form whatever; or to prate about the wanderings of Osiris and Isis, the plots of Typhon, the flight of Cronos, his eating his children and the slaughter of his father.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 75:3
verses.text: For this is your wisdom.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 75:4
verses.text: But how, if you mock the Cross, do you not marvel at the resurrection? For the same men who told us of the latter wrote the former.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 75:5
verses.text: Or why when you make mention of the Cross are you silent about the dead who were raised, the blind who received their sight, the paralytics who were healed, the lepers who were cleansed, the walking upon the sea, and the rest of the signs and wonders, which shew that Christ is no longer a man but God? To me you seem to do yourselves much injustice and not to have carefully read our Scriptures.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 75:6
verses.text: But read and see that the deeds of Christ prove Him to be God come upon earth for the salvation of men.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 76:2
verses.text: But do you tell us your religious beliefs.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 76:3
verses.text: What can you say of senseless creatures except senselessness and ferocity? But if, as I hear, you wish to say that these things are spoken of by you as legends, and you allegorize the rape of the maiden Persephone of the earth; the lameness of Hephaestus of fire; and allegorize the air as Hera, the sun as Apollo, the moon as Artemis, and the sea as Poseidon; none the less, you do not worship God Himself, but serve the creature rather than God who created all things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 76:4
verses.text: For if because creation is beautiful you composed such legends, still it was fitting that you should stop short at admiration and not make gods of the things created; so that you should not give the honour of the Creator to that which is created.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 76:5
verses.text: Since, if you do, it is time for you to divert the honour of the master builder to the house built by him; and of the general to the soldier.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 76:6
verses.text: What then can you reply to these things, that we may know whether the Cross hath anything worthy of mockery?'.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 77:2
verses.text: But when they were at a loss, turning hither and thither, Antony smiled and said—again through an interpreter—'Sight itself carries the conviction of these things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 77:3
verses.text: But as you prefer to lean upon demonstrative arguments, and as you, having this art, wish us also not to worship God, until after such proof, do you tell first how things in general and specially the recognition of God are accurately known.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 77:4
verses.text: Is it through demonstrative argument or the working of faith? And which is better, faith which comes through the inworking (of God) or demonstration by arguments?' And when they answered that faith which comes through the inworking was better and was accurate knowledge, Antony said, 'You have answered well, for faith arises from disposition of soul, but dialectic from the skill of its inventors.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 77:5
verses.text: Wherefore to those who have the inworking through faith, demonstrative argument is needless, or even superfluous.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 77:6
verses.text: For what we know through faith this you attempt to prove through words, and often you are not even able to express what we understand.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 77:7
verses.text: So the inworking through faith is better and stronger than your professional arguments.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 78:2
verses.text: 'We Christians therefore hold the mystery not in the wisdom of Greek arguments, but in the power of faith richly supplied to us by God through Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 78:3
verses.text: And to show that this statement is true, behold now, without having learned letters, we believe in God, knowing through His works His providence over all things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 78:4
verses.text: And to show that our faith is effective, so now we are supported by faith in Christ, but you by professional logomachies.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 78:5
verses.text: The portents of the idols among you are being done away, but our faith is extending everywhere.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 78:6
verses.text: You by your arguments and quibbles have converted none from Christianity to Paganism.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 78:7
verses.text: We, teaching the faith on Christ, expose your superstition, since all recognise that Christ is God and the Son of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 78:8
verses.text: You by your eloquence do not hinder the teaching of Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 78:9
verses.text: But we by the mention of Christ crucified put all demons to flight, whom you fear as if they were gods.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 78:10
verses.text: Where the sign of the Cross is, magic is weak and witchcraft has no strength.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 79:2
verses.text: 'Tell us therefore where your oracles are now? Where are the charms of the Egyptians? Where the delusions of the magicians? When did all these things cease and grow weak except when the Cross of Christ arose? Is It then a fit subject for mockery, and not rather the things brought to nought by it, and convicted of weakness? For this is a marvellous thing, that your religion was never persecuted, but even was honoured by men in every city, while the followers of Christ are persecuted, and still our side flourishes and multiplies over yours.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 79:3
verses.text: What is yours, though praised and honoured, perishes, while the faith and teaching of Christ, though mocked by you and often persecuted by kings, has filled the world.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 79:4
verses.text: For when has the knowledge of God so shone forth? or when has self-control and the excellence of virginity appeared as now? or when has death been so despised except when the Cross of Christ has appeared? And this no one doubts when he sees the martyr despising death for the sake of Christ, when he sees for Christ's sake the virgins of the Church keeping themselves pure and undefiled.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:2
verses.text: 'And these signs are sufficient to prove that the faith of Christ alone is the true religion.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:3
verses.text: But see! you still do not believe and are seeking for arguments.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:4
verses.text: We however make our proof "not in the persuasive words of Greek wisdom" as our teacher has it, but we persuade by the faith which manifestly precedes argumentative proof.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:5
verses.text: Behold there are here some vexed with demons;'—now there were certain who had come to him very disquieted by demons, and bringing them into the midst he said,—'Do you cleanse them either by arguments and by whatever art or magic you choose, calling upon your idols, or if you are unable, put away your strife with us and you shall see the power of the Cross of Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:6
verses.text: ' And having said this he called upon Christ, and signed the sufferers two or three times with the sign of the Cross.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:7
verses.text: And immediately the men stood up whole, and in their right mind, and forthwith gave thanks unto the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:8
verses.text: And the philosophers, as they are called, wondered, and were astonished exceedingly at the understanding of the man and at the sign which had been wrought.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:9
verses.text: But Antony said, 'Why marvel ye at this? We are not the doers of these things, but it is Christ who worketh them by means of those who believe on Him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:10
verses.text: Believe, therefore, also yourselves, and you shall see that with us there is no trick of words, but faith through love which is wrought in us towards Christ; which if you yourselves should obtain you will no longer seek demonstrative arguments, but will consider faith in Christ sufficient.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:11
verses.text: ' These are the words of Antony.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 80:12
verses.text: And they marvelling at this also, saluted him and departed, confessing the benefit they had received from him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 81:2
verses.text: And the fame of Antony came even unto kings.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 81:3
verses.text: For Constantine Augustus, and his sons Constantius and Constans the Augusti wrote letters to him, as to a father, and begged an answer from him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 81:4
verses.text: But he made nothing very much of the letters, nor did he rejoice at the messages, but was the same as he had been before the Emperors wrote to him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 81:5
verses.text: But when they brought him the letters he called the monks and said, 'Do not be astonished if an emperor writes to us, for he is a man; but rather wonder that God wrote the Law for men and has spoken to us through His own Son.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 81:6
verses.text: ' And so he was unwilling to receive the letters, saying that he did not know how to write an answer to such things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 81:7
verses.text: But being urged by the monks because the emperors were Christians, and lest they should take offence on the ground that they had been spurned, he consented that they should be read, and wrote an answer approving them because they worshipped Christ, and giving them counsel on things pertaining to salvation: 'not to think much of the present, but rather to remember the judgment that is coming, and to know that Christ alone was the true and Eternal King.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 81:8
verses.text: ' He begged them to be merciful and to give heed to justice and the poor.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 81:9
verses.text: And they having received the answer rejoiced.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 81:10
verses.text: Thus he was dear to all, and all desired to consider him as a father.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:2
verses.text: Being known to be so great a man, therefore, and having thus given answers to those who visited him, he returned again to the inner mountain, and maintained his wonted discipline.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:3
verses.text: And often when people came to him, as he was sitting or walking, as it is written in Daniel, he became dumb, and after a season he resumed the thread of what he had been saying before to the brethren who were with him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:4
verses.text: And his companions perceived that he was seeing a vision.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:5
verses.text: For often when he was on the mountains he saw what was happening in Egypt, and told it to Serapion the bishop, who was indoors with him, and who saw that Antony was wrapped in a vision.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:6
verses.text: Once as he was sitting and working, he fell, as it were, into a trance, and groaned much at what he saw.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:7
verses.text: Then after a time, having turned to the bystanders with groans and trembling, he prayed, and falling on his knees remained so a long time.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:8
verses.text: And having arisen the old man wept.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:9
verses.text: His companions, therefore, trembling and terrified, desired to learn from him what it was.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:10
verses.text: And they troubled him much, until he was forced to speak.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:11
verses.text: And with many groans he spake as follows: 'O, my children, it were better to die before what has appeared in the vision come to pass.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:12
verses.text: ' And when again they asked him, having burst into tears, he said, 'Wrath is about to seize the Church, and it is on the point of being given up to men who are like senseless beasts.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:13
verses.text: For I saw the table of the Lord's House, and mules standing around it on all sides in a ring, and kicking the things therein, just like a herd kicks when it leaps in confusion.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:14
verses.text: And you saw,' said he, 'how I groaned, for I heard a voice saying, "My altar shall be defiled".

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:15
verses.text: ' These things the old man saw, and after two years the present inroad of the Arians and the plunder of the churches took place, when they violently carried off the vessels, and made the heathen carry them; and when they forced the heathen from the prisons to join in their services, and in their presence did upon the Table as they would.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:16
verses.text: Then we all understood that these kicks of the mules signified to Antony what the Arians, senselessly like beasts, are now doing.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:17
verses.text: But when he saw this vision, he comforted those with him, saying, 'Be not downcast, my children; for as the Lord has been angry, so again will He heal us, and the Church shall soon again receive her own order, and shall shine forth as she is wont.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:18
verses.text: And you shall behold the persecuted restored, and wickedness again withdrawn to its own hiding-place, and pious faith speaking boldly in every place with all freedom.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 82:19
verses.text: Only defile not yourselves with the Arians, for their teaching is not that of the Apostles, but that of demons and their father the devil; yea, rather, it is barren and senseless, and without light understanding, like the senselessness of these mules.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 83:2
verses.text: Such are the words of Antony, and we ought not to doubt whether such marvels were wrought by the hand of a man.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 83:3
verses.text: For it is the promise of the Saviour, when He saith, 'If ye have faith as a grain of mustard seed, ye shall say to this mountain, remove hence and it shall remove; and nothing shall be impossible unto you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 83:4
verses.text: ' And again, 'Verily, verily, I say unto you, if ye shall ask the father in My name He will give it you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 83:5
verses.text: Ask and ye shall receive.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 83:6
verses.text: ' And He himself it is who saith to His disciples and to all who believe on Him, 'Heal the sick, cast out demons; freely ye have received, freely give.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 84:2
verses.text: Antony, at any rate, healed not by commanding, but by prayer and speaking the name of Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 84:3
verses.text: So that it was clear to all that it was not he himself who worked, but the Lord who showed mercy by his means and healed the sufferers.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 84:4
verses.text: But Antony's part was only prayer and discipline, for the sake of which he stayed in the mountain, rejoicing in the contemplation of divine things, but grieving when troubled by much people, and dragged to the outer mountain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 84:5
verses.text: For all judges used to ask him to come down, because it was impossible for them to enter on account of their following of litigants.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 84:6
verses.text: But nevertheless they asked him to come that they might but see him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 84:7
verses.text: When therefore he avoided it and refused to go to them, they remained firm, and sent to him all the more the prisoners under charge of soldiers, that on account of these he might come down.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 84:8
verses.text: Being forced by necessity, and seeing them lamenting, he came into the outer mountain, and again his labour was not unprofitable.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 84:9
verses.text: For his coming was advantageous and serviceable to many; and he was of profit to the judges, counselling them to prefer justice to all things; to fear God, and to know, 'that with what judgment they judged, they should be judged.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 84:10
verses.text: ' But he loved more than all things his sojourn in the mountain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 85:2
verses.text: At another time, suffering the same compulsion at the hands of them who had need, and after many entreaties from the commander of the soldiers, he came down, and when he was come he spoke to them shortly of the things which make for salvation, and concerning those who wanted him, and was hastening away.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 85:3
verses.text: But when the duke, as he is called, entreated him to stay, he replied that he could not linger among them, and persuaded him by a pretty simile, saying, 'Fishes, if they remain long on dry land, die.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 85:4
verses.text: And so monks lose their strength if they loiter among you and spend their time with you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 85:5
verses.text: Wherefore as fish must hurry to the sea, so must we hasten to the mountain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 85:6
verses.text: Lest haply if we delay we forget the things within us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Life of Antony 85:7
